{{BLP sources|date=October 2013}} {{Use American English|date=May 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Alfred Ford (Ambarish Das) | image = Alfred Ford (Ambarisha Das) Tirupati 31-01-2007.jpg| | image_size = 200px | | other_names = Ambarish Das | caption = Alfred Ford at ISKCON temple, Tirupati, India, in 2007 | birth_date = 1950 | birth_place = [[Detroit]], Michigan, U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | known = | occupation = [[Businessman]] | title =Chairman of [[ISKCON]] project
Chairman of Temple of the Vedic Planetarium{{cite news|title=Alfred B Ford On Gujarat Tour To Raise Funds For ISKCON Temple|url=http://m.vishwagujarat.com/gujarat/alfred-b-ford-on-gujarat-tour-to-raise-funds-for-iskcon-temple/|accessdate=1 February 2017|work=Vishwa Gujarat|date=29 January 2017|location =India}}{{cite news|title=Ford scion in Gujarat to raise funds for ISKCON temple|url=http://m.timesofindia.com/city/ahmedabad/ford-scion-in-state-to-raise-funds-for-iskcon-temple/articleshow/56841364.cms|accessdate=1 February 2017|work=[[Times of India]]|date=29 January 2017|location=India}} | salary = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards =[[Ford Motor Company]] | spouse = Sharmila Ford | children = Amrita and Anisha | relations = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Alfred Brush Ford''' (born 1950), also known as '''Ambarish Das''', is an [[United States|American]] heir to the Ford fortune. He is a great-grandson of legendary businessman [[Henry Ford]] - the founder of the [[Ford Motor Company]]. ==Background== {{See also|Ford family tree}} Ford is the son of Walter B. Ford II (1920–1991), whose family were prominent in chemical manufacturing in the Downriver area south of Detroit. His late mother, Josephine Clay Ford (1923–2005) was the daughter of [[Edsel Ford]] (1893–1943), who was the son of Henry Ford (1863–1947).{{cite news|title=Alfred Ford is Building a Multi-Million Dollar Monument in India|url=http://www.townandcountrymag.com/society/money-and-power/news/a4350/alfred-ford-multi-million-dollar-monument-india/|accessdate=12 September 2016|publisher=Town & Country|date=23 November 2015}} Thus both his father and mother were born with the last name of Ford. Alfred and [[William Clay Ford, Jr.]] (b. 1957), the current executive chairman of the Ford Motor Co., are first cousins. Alfred's mother was the sister of [[William Clay Ford, Sr.]] (1925–2014; William Ford, Jr.'s father). He currently serves on the board of directors of privately held digital marketing firm [[ChannelNet]], where he is also an investor. Ford Motor Company was one of ChannelNet's early clients.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} ==Association with the Hare Krishna Movement== {{Vaishnavism}} He is an initiated disciple of [[A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada]] (Srila Prabhupada) since 1974. He first met Bhaktivedanta Swami in [[Dallas]], USA.{{YouTube|UIIygo5-qeU}} Alfred Ford joined the [[International Society for Krishna Consciousness]] (the ''[[International Society for Krishna Consciousness|Hare Krishnas]]'') in 1975 and that same year he made his first trip to [[India]] with Prabhupada. He assisted in the establishment of the first Hindu temple in [[Hawaii]] and also donated $500,000 to help establish the [[Bhaktivedanta Cultural Center]] in [[Detroit]]{{cite news | title = Article in The New York Times | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E06E3DA1E39F93AA35752C1A967948260 | accessdate = August 25, 2006 | first1=Albin | last1=Krebs | date=November 9, 1981}} which was completed in 1983. Alfred Ford has made many significant donations to ISKCON over the years which have assisted ongoing projects to build the Pushpa Samadhi Mandir of Prabhupada. He is the chairman of the Sri Mayapur Temple of the Vedic Planetarium (also called TOVP).{{cite web|title=Temple of Vedic Planeterium - meet-the-team|url=http://tovp.org/en/about-us/meet-the-team|publisher=Temple of Vedic Planeterium|accessdate=31 May 2012}} Ford is said to have supported the construction of a [[Vedic period|Vedic]] cultural centre in [[Moscow]] at an estimated cost of $10 million.{{cite web|title=Article in vnn.org |url=http://www.vnn.org/world/WD0310/WD21-8417.html |accessdate=August 25, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070805045124/http://www.vnn.org/world/WD0310/WD21-8417.html |archivedate=August 5, 2007 }} He also bought a $600,000 mansion to house a Hare Krishna temple and learning centre in [[Honolulu]].{{cite news | title = The Billionaire Bhakta | url = http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/articleshow/msid-1042366,curpg-1.cms | accessdate = August 25, 2006 | work=The Times Of India | first1=Malavika | last1=Sangghvi | date=March 6, 2005}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.tovp.org Temple of the Vedic Planetarium] {{Modern Gaudiya Vaishnavas}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ford, Alfred}} [[Category:Converts to Hinduism from Christianity]] [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Henry Ford family]] [[Category:American Hindus]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American Hare Krishnas]] [[Category:Date of birth missing (living people)]]

{{more footnotes|date=September 2010}} [[Image:Alfredo Harp Helu.jpg|thumb|Alfredo Harp Helú]] '''Alfredo Harp Helú''' (born 1944) is a [[Mexican people|Mexican]] businessman of Lebanese origin, and as of 2011, with a net worth of $1.5 [[1000000000 (number)|billion]], is according to [[Forbes]] the 974th richest person in the world. He is also the cousin of [[Carlos Slim Helu]], who as of 2013 is the second richest person in the world as ranked by Forbes
In 2018, Alfredo Harp Helu ranked #1867 on the ''Forbes'' World's Billionaires list, with wealth listed at US $1.2 billion.<ref>https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/list/3/#version:static_header:source</ref>
== Biography == Born in [[Mexico City]], Harp is most famous for being the former owner of the biggest [[Latin American]] and Mexican [[bank]], [[Banamex]] (now part of [[Citigroup]]), and was a billion-dollar beneficiary of Citigroup's 2001 [[buyout]] of [[Banamex]]. He is also owner of the [[telecommunication]] company, [[Avantel]], the second largest telephone company in Mexico (now part of [[Axtel]]).
==Personal life== Harp is married, with several children. He and his family with his second wife divide their time between homes in Mexico City and [[Oaxaca, Oaxaca|Oaxaca City]].
He is a baseball fan, owning wholly or partly two professional baseball teams in Mexico, the Diablos Rojos of Mexico City and the [[Guerreros de Oaxaca|Guerreros]] of Oaxaca City.
=== Kidnapping === In 1994, Harp's family paid about $30 million after he was held for 106 days by his [[kidnap]]pers in Mexico City. The release followed a dramatic [[television]] appearance in which his son, accompanied by a family [[lawyer]] and a [[priest]], accepted the kidnappers' terms unconditionally. At the family's request, the police did not intervene, giving rise to fears that the huge [[ransom]] would encourage more kidnappings, and adding to concerns about [[Mexico]]'s stability. In 1996, authorities claimed to have recovered nearly $10 million of the Harp ransom.
In 2008, Harp attended the funeral of Fernando Martí, 14-year-old son of the founder of a chain of sporting goods stores, who had been kidnapped and murdered, despite his family's payment of a ransom. He also paid for a full-page advertisement in newspapers calling on the government to put a stop to the rising kidnapping phenomenon in Mexico.
== Philanthropy == Harp funds several charitable foundations: * Fundación Alfredo Harp Helú * Fundación Alfredo Harp Helú Oaxaca (involved in education, health, culture, and conservation in the state of [[Oaxaca]]).
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051106011635/http://timelines.ws/20thcent/1994C.HTML Timeline 1994 C] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090418193831/http://alfredoharphelu.com/PERSONAL/default.aspx Alfredo Harp Helu personal] * [http://www.fahh.com.mx/ Fundación Alfredo Harp Helú] * [http://www.fahho.org/ Fundación Alfredo Harp Helú Oaxaca]
== References == {{Reflist}} * [https://www.nytimes.com/1994/06/25/world/family-of-kidnapped-mexican-financier-agrees-to-ransom.html The New York Times - Family of Kidnapped Mexican Financier Agrees to Ransom] (June 1994) * [http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1830649,00.html Time - No Help for Mexico's Kidnapping Surge] (August 2008) * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7553633.stm BBC - Mexican fury grows at kidnappings] (August 2008)
{{Authority control}}

{{Chinese name|[[Hu (surname)|Aw (胡)]]}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = Dato | name = Aw Cheng Chye | honorific_suffix = [[Order of the Crown of Johor|S.P.M.J.]], [[Bintang Bakti Masyarakat|B.B.M.]], [[Order of Saint John (chartered 1888)|O.St.J]] | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1 January 1924 | birth_place = [[Rangoon]], Burma | death_date = {{death date and age|1971|8|22|1923|1|1|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Santiago]], Chile | death_cause = stroke | nationality = {{aligned table|fullwidth=y|style=text-align: left; font-size: 100%;|[[British subject]]|(1923–1958)|Singapore{{#tag:ref|Singapore Citizenship Ordinance is passed in 1957, State of Singapore Act a year after, both defined the citizenship of Singapore (within British subject), and the self-rule of Singapore as a state within the commonwealth; Malaysian during Singapore as a member of the Federation of Malaysia, 1963–1965|group="nb"}}|(1958–1971)|China{{#tag:ref|by the birth of a Chinese citizen. No source indicated that he activated the citizenship of Republic of China, People's Republic of China or Republic of China (Taiwan).|group="nb"}}|}} | other_names = | occupation = {{ubl|businessman|company director|philanthropist}} | awards = | boards = {{ubl|[[Singapore Chinese Football Club|Singapore Chinese FA]]|[[Singapore Red Cross]]|[[Singapore National Olympic Council|Singapore Olympic Council]]|<hr>|Haw Par Brothers (Pte.)|[[Haw Par Corporation|Haw Par Brothers Int'l]]|[[Sin Poh (Star News) Amalgamated|Sin Poh Amalgamated]]|[[Chung Khiaw Bank]]}} | years_active = | parents = {{aligned table|fullwidth=y|style=text-align: left; font-size: 100%;|{{nowrap|[[Aw Boon Par]]}}|(father)|Daw Saw|(biological mum)<ref name=book/><ref name=dictionary/>|Tay Piah Lan|(mother)<ref name=mum group=nb/><ref name=dictionary>{{cite book|title=Southeast Asian Personalities of Chinese Descent|url=https://books.google.com.au/books?id=v9QEBAAAQBAJ|date=2012|access-date=11 October 2017|publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies|page=497|publication-place=Singapore|first=Leo |last=Suryadinata}}</ref>|Teo Hong Yin|(mother){{#tag:ref|At the time Chinese culture allowed multiple wives, Tay Piah Lan was the first and Daw Saw was the second|group="nb"|name="mum"}}<ref>http://www.amo.gov.hk/form/HIA_Report_HPM.pdf</ref>}} | spouse = Tay Chwee Sian (1949–1971†)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19490923-1.2.56|title=Registry Wedding For Colony Millionaire|date=23 September 1949|access-date=11 October 2017|work=The Straits Times|publication-place=Singapore|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> | relatives = {{aligned table|fullwidth=y|style=text-align: left; font-size: 100%;|{{nowrap|Aw Cheng Taik}}|(brother)|Aw Cheng Hu|(sister)|Aw Cheng Sin|(sister)|[[Aw Chu Kin]]|(grandfather)|{{nowrap|[[Aw Boon Haw]]}}|(uncle)|Tay Kee Ming|(father-in-law)}} | children = {{aligned table|fullwidth=y|style=text-align: left; font-size: 100%;|Aw Toke Soon|(son)|Aw Toke Ghee|(son)|Aw Toke Ho|(son)|Aw Ai Sim|(daughter)}} | known_for = | notable_works = }} {{Chinese|title=Aw Cheng Chye|c=胡清才|p=Hú Qīngcái|j=Wu<sup>4</sup> Cing<sup>1</sup> Coi<sup>4</sup> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chineseconverter.com|title=Chinese Converter - Learn Chinese Tools|website=www.chineseconverter.com}}</ref>}} '''[[Malay styles and titles|Dato]] Aw Cheng Chye''' <small>[[Order of the Crown of Johor|S.P.M.J.]], [[Bintang Bakti Masyarakat|B.B.M.]], [[Order of Saint John (chartered 1888)|O.St.J]]</small> (1 January<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19720101-1.2.74.16|title=胡清才家屬撥欵四千元分別捐贈四間慈善團體|date=1 January 1972|access-date=10 October 2017|work=[[Nanyang Siang Pau (Singapore)|Nanyang Siang Pau]]|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> 1924<ref>{{cite book|script-title=傳記文學雜誌 第五十五卷|language=zh}}</ref> – 22 August 1971) was a Singaporean millionaire and son of the late [[Aw Boon Par]]. Aw Cheng Chye himself was the chairman of Haw Par Brothers (Private) Limited and [[Haw Par Corporation|Haw Par Brothers International Limited]] until his sudden death on 22 August 1971 in [[Santiago de Chile]].
==Biography== ===Early life=== Aw Cheng Chye was born in [[Rangoon]], [[British Burma]] of [[Hakka Chinese]] descent.<ref name=Awfamily/> At young age, Aw Cheng Chye inherited part of the wealth of his father, who died in 1944.
===Business career=== Aw Cheng Chye became a deputy to his uncle [[Aw Boon Haw]] to manage family business in Singapore in the 1950s, which saw Aw Cheng Chye was a director of an insurance company Public Insurance ({{zh|t=大衆保險}}) in 1951, while Aw Boon Haw was the chairman.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19510315-1.2.35.14|title=大衆保險公司董事選定|date=15 March 1951|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19541007-1.2.35.7|title=大眾人壽保險公司正副主席選定|date=7 October 1954|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19541011-1.2.146|title=Bosses are changed in 2 companies|date=11 October 1954|access-date=10 October 2017|work=The Straits Times|publication-place=Singapore|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> Aw Cheng Chye remained as a shareholder and a director at least until circa 1960s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19620724-1.2.23.16|title=大衆保險公司昨開常年股東大會 |date=24 July 1962|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> He also served as a director of the sister company Public Life Assurance ({{zh|t=大眾人壽保險}}).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19550715-1.2.170.6|title=Insurance company formed|date=15 July 1955|access-date=10 October 2017|work=The Straits Times|publication-place=Singapore|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> When the incorporation of [[Sin Poh Amalgamated (Hong Kong)]] in 1951, he also received 60 shares out of 1500, and Aw Cheng Chye's son Aw Toke Soon, 30 shares.<ref>{{cite book|title=1952 Annual Return of Sin Poh Amalgamated (H.K.) Limited|date=30 December 1952|publisher=Hong Kong Company Registries}}</ref> His brother Aw Cheng Taik was a director, along with Aw Boon Haw and his sons and daughter Aw Swan, Sally Aw and Aw It Haw, who resides in Hong Kong at that time.
After the death of Aw Boon Haw in 1954, Aw Cheng Chye became the chairman of Haw Par Brothers (Private) which owned the majority of family assets and business, (except Hong Kong newspapers). The shareholder of the holding company including his relatives, such as [[Sally Aw]] who inherited the Hong Kong newspapers and based in Hong Kong. According to Aw Boon Haw's will, Sally Aw was responsible for the sale of the assets under Boon Haw name, and requested (but not legally binding) her to use part or whole in charity.<ref>{{cite news|title= Mogul's will puts end to mystery|date=5 April 1998|work=South China Morning Post|publication-place=Hong Kong|via=[[Factiva]]|first=Gren|last=Manuel}}</ref> The lawsuit of the heritage of Aw Boon Haw was settled in 1967, which Haw Par Brothers (Private) reclaimed assets based in Hong Kong which were mistaken to be the private heritage of Boon Haw. Sally Aw paid the company [[Singapore dollar|S$]]1.7 million as compensation.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19670509-1.2.93|title=Aw family dispute is settled for [S]$1.7 m|date=9 May 1967|access-date=9 October 2017|work=[[The Straits Times]]|location=Hong Kong|publication-place=Singapore|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
Aw Cheng Chye was also the mastermind of the offer to sell the [[Tiger Balm Garden (Hong Kong)|Haw Par Mansion]] and its gardens of Hong Kong in 1961.<ref name=mansion1961/> The mansion was owned by the holding company,<ref name=mansion1961>{{cite news|title=新聞人物胡一虎接見記者|date=24 October 1961|page=6|work=Ta Kung Pao|publication-place=Hong Kong|via=Hong Kong Public Libraries|language=Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19611024-1.2.20.9|title=香港虎豹別墅求售 胡仙大表驚 異謂永遠保存別墅乃其父遺志 使其永久成爲市民遊憩之所|date=24 October 1961|orig-year=Written on 20 October 1961|location=Hong Kong|access-date=7 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=今晨南華早報刊出出售虎豹別墅廣告 胡仙聲明對此甚感詫異|date=20 October 1961|page=4|work=The Kung Sheung Evening News|publication-place=Hong Kong|language=Chinese|via=Hong Kong Public Libraries}}</ref> but lived by Sally Aw until 1998.
Aw Cheng Chye took most of the assets of Haw Par Brothers (Private) public by incorporating a new holding company [[Haw Par Corporation|Haw Par Brothers International Limited]] in July 1969, but not including the Haw Par Mansions, only leasing them to the company; not all the stake of [[Chung Khiaw Bank]] was injected to the listed company either.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Page/straitstimes19691112-1.1.6|title=Prospectus|author=Haw Par Brothers International|work=The Straits Times|date=12 November 1969|pages=6 to 7|publication-place=Singapore|access-date=8 October 2017|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> He also privatized [[Sin Poh (Star News) Amalgamated]], a subsidiary of Haw Par Brothers International in June 1971.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19710613-1.2.13.10|title=星系報業屬下三家報完全歸胡氏家族所有史勒特華克並未取得擁有權|date=13 June 1971|access-date=7 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> Both companies were chaired by Aw Cheng Chye. In the same month [[Slater Walker]] acquired the controlling stake of the listed company. In the same month, 49.8% stake of Chung Khiaw Bank was sold by Haw Par Brothers International to [[United Overseas Bank]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19710619-1.2.11.5|title=大華銀行經已取得 崇僑銀行平衡股權 虎豹出售股權値二千二百萬元|date=19 June 1971|access-date=11 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> just few days after the staff of the bank opposed the takeover of a foreign firm.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19710617-1.2.15.2|title=星馬股票交易所總經 理要求虎豹兄弟公司 澄清所作聲明真相 祟僑銀行兩董事及兩高級職員代表 促董事主席勿讓該行為外國人操縱|date=17 June 1971|access-date=11 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> The president of the bank Lee Chee Shan, sister-in-law of Aw Cheng Chye, retired in July 1971.<ref name=bank/>
Shortly after the takeover of Haw Par Brothers International, Cheng Chye was found dead during a vacation trip in [[Santiago de Chile]] on 22 August 1971.<ref name=death>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19710830-1.2.13.15|title=星系報業暨虎豹兄弟公司主席胡淸才靈柩運返星 下月一日發引還山 李總理特函胡夫人致唁|date=30 August 1971|access-date=8 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> [[Lee Kuan Yew]], Prime Minister of Singapore also wrote a public pleading to Aw family.<ref name=death/>
Upon his death, he chaired Haw Par Brothers International<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19710605-1.2.21.2|title=拿督胡清才博士續任虎豹兄弟國際有限公司主席|date=5 June 1971|access-date=8 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> and as a director of [[Chung Khiaw Bank]].<ref name=bank>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19710820-1.2.48.14|title=拿督李志成再被委為崇僑銀行總裁惟屬名譽性質|date=20 August 1971|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> He also served as a director of many companies<ref name=Awfamily/> and in public organizations such as Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19710215-1.2.17.1|title=中華總商會卅六屆董事 全部人選揭曉 本月底複選正副會長與各組主任|date=15 February 1971|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19710902-1.2.31.3|title=總商會邀李慶傳出任福建帮董事補故胡淸才遺缺|date=2 September 1971|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
He was a director of [[Robinson & Co.]] in 1963,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19630311-1.2.32.11|title=股市意態闌珊|date=11 March 1963|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> and chairman of Rothmans Singapore in 1966<ref name=Rothmans>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19660218-1.2.128|title=$100,000 gift for S'pore sport|date=18 February 1966|access-date=10 October 2017|work=The Straits Times|publication-place=Singapore|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> and [[Life Records|Life Record Industries]] in 1969.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19691225-1.2.28|title= 錄音造模製片分色印刷裝套齊備我國第一間完整生產唱片製造廠麗風唱片工業（私人）有限公司明日敦請社會事務部長奧斯曼渥主持開幕設備與人才均屬第一流堪與世界水準媲美|date=25 December 1969|access-date=11 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> Under the chairmanship of Aw Cheng Chye, Rothmans donated S$100,000 to the [[Singapore Sports Council]] ({{zh|t=新加坡全國體育協會}}).<ref name=Rothmans/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19660218-1.2.26.7|title=樂富門烟草（星）有限公司 捐鉅款十萬元 充體育協會今年度體育基金 該公司董事主席拿督胡淸才 昨晚親將支票移交社會部長|date=18 February 1966|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
===Public organization=== Aw Cheng Chye served in Singapore Anti-Tuberculosis Association ({{zh|t=新加坡防癆協會}}), the predecessor of SATA CommHealth in 1967<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19670429-1.2.38.2|title=防癆協會理事會本年新職員選出|date=29 April 1967|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> as well as the vice-president of the [[Singapore Red Cross Society]], only deputy to the wife of the prime minister, [[Kwa Geok Choo]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19670112-1.2.35.18|title=國際紅十字會會長古納伉儷昨晨謁見新加坡總統及夫人|date= 12 January 1967|access-date=10 news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19601228-1.2.47.1|title=中醫師公會 昨開第八次理事會議 第一分院籌辦繼續展開 决出版星馬中醫藥學報|date=28 December 1960|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19600926-1.2.16.4|title=捐血者公會正式成立 旨在協助輸血組工作 衛生部長讚佩慷慨捐血人士 九十名捐血者獲贈金銀獎牌|date=26 September 1960|access-date=10 October news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19620309-1.2.36.1|title=南洋客屬總會贊成 今年底在香港舉行 世界客屬聯誼會 將派代表團赴港參加 總會昨舉行新董事就職禮 會長張夢生晚間設春酌歡宴全體董事|date=9 March 1962|access-date=10 October To sum up, he followed the footstep of his uncle Aw Boon Par as a philanthropist, but also involved in the day-to-day operation of the organizations.
===Sports=== Aw Cheng Chye was the president of the [[Singapore Chinese Football Club]]{{#tag:ref|{{zh|s=新加坡华人足球会}}, also known as The Singapore Chinese Football Association,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19540415-1.2.196|title= S.C.F.A. APPOINT DELEGATES|date=15 April 1954|access-date=10 October 2017|work=The Straits Times|publication-place=Singapore|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> which was a sub-association of [[Football Association of Singapore|Singapore Amateur Football Association]] and Malaysian Chinese Football Association (M.C.F.A.).|group="nb"}} from 1954 to 1955.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/lhwb19840628-1.2.15.4|title=新加坡华人足球会历任会长（到50年代）|date=28 June 1984|access-date=10 October 2017|work=[[Lianhe Wanbao]]|publisher=Singapore News and Publications|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> He also served as the vice-chairman of {{zh|t=馬華體育促進會|l=Malaysian Chinese Sports Association}} in 1957<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19570402-1.2.30.1|title= 馬華體育促進會昨舉行會議第四屆南大杯籃球賽各小組委員全部選出十六日討論邀請那一些國家派隊參加|date=2 April 1957|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> and vice-president of Singapore Chinese Swimming Club ({{zh|t=新加坡中華游泳會}}) in 1962.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19620503-1.2.38.9|title=中華游泳會改選吳佛吉蟬聯會長|date=3 May 1962|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> He sponsored S$2,000 to Singapore Chinese Swimming Club in January 1964 <ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19640131-1.2.8.6.1|title=星中華游泳會訂期舉行游泳賽孫炳炎吁大家衷誠合作更一步推進中華會會務|date=31 January 1964|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> as well as elected as an honorary president in May 1964.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Page/nysp19640504-1.1.7|title=中華游泳會昨選舉理事 孫炳炎榮任正會長 談開源方法在增加會員 刷新原有設備 融洽會員情感|date=4 May 1964|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> In the 1960s, he was an honorary president of Basketball Association of Singapore.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19610123-1.2.30.1|title=星業餘籃總改選 吳再興莊卓岩膺選蟬聯正副會長 重要職員人選頗多變動面目一新 沈時潤張修憲東山再起領導籃運|date=23 January 1961|access-date=11 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19620310-1.2.19.1|title=邀請九國參加小亞洲金杯賽 籃總發出請柬 理事會决定邀世界杯勁旅來星 授權會長負責辦理有關邀請事 興建籃球場建議保留下屆理事會議討論|date=10 March 1962|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
Aw Cheng Chye was elected as the vice-president of [[Singapore National Olympic Council]] in 1954. He was the delegate for the Singapore Amateur Boxing Association of Singapore,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19540730-1.2.26.3|title=星奧會選出新職員 陳才淸蟬聯正會長 秘書史特蘭退休由拉惹繼任 經費無着不能參加温古華帝運會|date=30 July 1954|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> which he was the president.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19531231-1.2.26.1|title=本市業餘拳擊協會 派少年拳擊隊赴西澳 一行十八名今日乘輪出發 昨茶會市長勗各拳師母負所託|date=31 December 1953|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
Upon his death, Aw Cheng Chye was an honorary chairman of Malaysian Chinese Football Association.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19720328-1.2.27.3|title=馬華足總將通知 港今年和和杯埠際賽 十月七日在港舉行|date=28 March 1972|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
Aw Cheng Chye was one of the many honorary chairmen of Singapore [[Chin Woo Athletic Association]] ({{zh|t=新加坡精武體育會}}) in the 1950s<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19590122-1.2.38.7|title=社團消息|date=22 January 1959|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> and 1960s,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19670123-1.2.15.22|title=精武體育會選出各部門幹事職員|date=23 January 1967|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19690423-1.2.36.24|title=精武體育會選出今明年度新職員|date=23 April 1969|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> as well as Singapore [[Fujian White Crane|Pak Hock Pai]] Athletic Association ({{zh|t=新加坡白鶴派體育會}})<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19690209-1.2.41.5|title=星白鶴派體育會廿一屆職員舉行宣誓就職禮由梁子庵監誓|date=9 February 1969|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19700125-1.2.53.5|title=星白鶴派體育會今年新理事選出陳國旋蟬聯正會長大部職員也獲連任|date=25 January 1970|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19700313-1.2.35.41|title=崇正國術體育會第四屆職員就職|date=13 March 1970|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang His uncle was once famous for his charity, as well as infamously credited as "shameless promoter" [of his product and himself] by [[Asiaweek]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/99/0212/cs1-2.html|title= CHEAP SELF-PROMOTION|date=12 February 1999|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Asiaweek|publication-place=Hong Kong|publisher=Time Warner}}</ref> However, Aw Cheng Chye also known for numerous sponsorship in sports. For example, a golf tournament was named after him in 1967,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19670124-1.2.19.8|title=胡淸才杯高爾夫球賽醫藥隊勝繪測隊|date=24 January Aw Cheng Chye was one of the sponsor of Cuesports Singapore ({{zh|t=新加坡檯球協會}}, later {{lang|zh|新加坡台球總會}}) for many years<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19590130-1.2.30.3|title=檯球協會選出新職員|date=30 January 1959|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19660210-1.2.35.8|title=星台球總會改選黄國良出任會長|date=10 February 1666|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19670305-1.2.35.6|title=星台球總會新職員選出|date=5 March 1967|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> as well as Singapore Table Tennis Association<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19700729-1.2.42.6|title=星乒乓總會新職員名單|date=29 July 1970|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> and a predecessor of Singapore Weightlifting Federation ({{zh|t=新加坡業餘舉重與健身總會}});<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19690201-1.2.52.3|title=星舉總開大會通過易名爲業餘舉重與健身總會蘇義順蟬聯正會長|date=1 February 1969|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> he was an honorary chairman in 1963.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19630115-1.2.46.3|title=八月舉辦大馬舉重大賽 星舉重總會首響應 對緬甸六國賽事現尚未接獲請東 舉重總會已向日本購置一副新道具|date=15 January 1963|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>

Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
==Legacy== Sin Chew Jit Poh Building in Singapore was known as Aw Cheng Chye Building. It was a property of Haw Par Brothers (Private) in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/scjp19820202-1.2.15.29|title=负责胡清才大廈建筑时收取五千元佣金 虎豹兄弟公司前秘书贪污罪成立被罚七千元|date=2 February 1982|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Sin Chew Jit Poh (Singapore)|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> A scholarship was set up in the [[University of Singapore]] in 1972 by Haw Par Brothers International for S$20,000 each year (initially up to 7 years).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19720823-1.2.15.14|title=虎豹兄弟國際有限公司爲紀念已故胡清才設醫學研究奬學金每年捐二萬元爲期七年|date=23 August 1972|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19740822-1.2.118|title=$20,000 Haw Par gift for varsity|date=22 August 1974|access-date=10 October 2017|work=The Straits Times|publication-place=Singapore|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
Aw Kow ({{zh|t=胡蛟}}), the eldest (adopted) son of the late Aw Boon Haw, sued Haw Par Brothers (Private) Limited in 1972 for blocking him to read its accounts and financial statements, claiming under the late Aw Cheng Chye, the company allowed personal spending of Aw Cheng Chye, was invoiced by the company itself.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19720912-1.2.16.1|title=胡蛟向高等法院請求發出命令禁止虎豹私人公司阻礙檢查賬目紀錄原告律師指故胡清才在任期問濫用職權利用公款充私人用途|date=12 September 1972|access-date=9 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> The lawsuit was settled in 1977 in favoured Aw Kow.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/newnation19770223-1.2.3|title=Aw suit settled|date=23 February 1977|access-date=10 October 2017|work=New Nation|publication-place=Singapore|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
In the autobiography ''[[Escape from Paradise]]'' by John & May Chu Harding, they also claimed that Aw Cheng Chye's decision to make Haw Par Brothers International public, was against the wish of the part of the Aw family.<ref name=book>{{cite book|title=Escape from Paradise: From Third World to First|first1=John|last1=Harding|first2=May Chu|last2=Lee|publisher=IDKPress|date=2001|publication-place=Phoenix|ISBN=0-9710929-0-7|via=Google Book preview}}</ref>{{rp|42}} May Chu Harding, ''née'' Lee, was the great-granddaughter of Aw Boon Par, or granddaughter of Lee Chee Shan and Aw Cheng Hu.<ref name=book/>{{rp|18}} Lee Chee Shan ({{zh|t=李志成}}) was the president of Chung Khiaw Bank,<ref name=Awfamily/> but retired in July 1971.<ref name=bank/>
The business empire of Haw Par Brothers International and Aw family was completely dismantled after the takeover and the death of Aw Cheng Chye in 1971. After the brother-in-law and sister of Aw Cheng Chye resigned as the directors of Thai subsidiary of Haw Par Brothers International, the Thai subsidiary, which was responsible to make "Tiger Balm" [[liniment]] in Thailand, was sold in 1972. A proposal to acquire the remaining shares of Chung Khiaw Bank by [[United Overseas Bank]], was announced in the same year. At that time due to the ability of director from the related parties being able to vote in such deal, a minority shareholder made a public statement on the newspaper, requesting the government to investigate.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19720623-1.2.58.12|title=祟僑銀行一股東的申訴|date=23 June 1972|access-date=11 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
==Awards== * Honorary degree of Doctor of Laws, [[Fairleigh Dickinson University]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19640608-1.2.28.3|title=胡淸才楊錫秋表感謝肯迪遜大學贈給學位|date=8 June 1964|access-date=10 October 2017|location=New Jersey|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
==Honorary titles== * Officer (O.St.J) of the [[Order of Saint John (chartered 1888)|Order of Saint John]] ([[St John Singapore]]) (1959 until his death)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19590915-1.2.26.2|title=聖約翰救傷隊總部訂期舉行授勳典禮十一人蒙英女皇頒賜勳章本月廿七日將由國家元首親臨頒發|date=15 September 1959|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> *[[Datuk|Dato]] Paduka Mahkota Johore (D.P.M.J.) of the [[Order of the Crown of Johor]] (1963–1968)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19631029-1.2.29.12|title=柔佛州臣民昨熱烈慶祝 蘇丹殿下六九華誕 新山舉行盛大閱兵禮水上運動會 六十四位有功臣民受封各級勳銜 胡淸才封拿督湯振波陳錦泉膺SMJ|date=29 October 1963|access-date=10 October 2017|location=Johor Bahru|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19631029-1.2.46|title=AW CHENG CHYE IS THE ONLY NEW DATO|date=29 October 1963|access-date=10 October 2017|work=The Straits Times|publication-place=Singapore|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> * Dato Sri Paduka Mahkota Johore (S.P.M.J.) of the Order of the Crown of Johor (1968 until his death)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19681028-1.2.16.10|title=柔佛蘇丹今日慶祝華誕封賜一六七人姚庭珊劉金鐘受封太平局紳新山巨刧案殉職警員獲追封|date=28 October 1968|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> * [[Bintang Bakti Masyarakat]] (BBM)<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19641115-1.2.27.1|title=二二七名對本州服務有功人士榮獲元首敦尤素夫頒發各級榮譽獎章元首夫人獲卓越服務獎|date=15 November 1964|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
==Personal life== Aw Cheng Chye married to Tay Chwee Sian ({{zh|t=鄭水仙}})<ref name=Awfamily>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/newnation19710723-1.2.45|title=The Aw family|work=New Nation|publication-place=Singapore|date=23 July 1971|access-date=6 October 2017|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref> also known as Datin Aw Cheng Chye. Aw Toke Soon ({{zh|t=胡督信}}), Toke Ghee ({{zh|s=胡督义}}) and Toke Ho are their son, as well daughter Aw Ai Sim.<ref name=Awfamily/><ref>{{cite new|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/scjp19810823-1.2.13.24|title=为纪念先父胡清才 胡督义赠送救伤车给我国红十字会|date=23 August 1981|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Sin Chew Jit Poh (Singapore)|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
After [[Sin Poh (Star News) Amalgamated]] selling the publishing rights of ''Sin Chew Jit Poh'' (Singapore) in 1975 to the company of the same name, Tay Chwee Sian and Aw Toke Soon retained management shares of the company until 1978. They gave up the management shares (converted to ordinary shares) as well as the chance to be elected as the directors of Sin Chew Jit Poh (Singapore) Limited in 1978.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19781007-1.2.145.12.3|title=Notice of extraordinary general meeting|date=7 October 1978|access-date=8 October 2017|author=Sin Chew Jit Poh (Singapore) Limited|work=The Straits Times|publication-place=Singapore|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19780824-1.2.15.10|title=星洲日报有限公司宣布委任四名新董事黃祖耀任新董事主席|date=24 August 1978|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau Singapore|publisher=Nanyang Press Singapore (1975) Limited|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/scjp19790529-1.2.75.20|title=本报营业获辉煌成绩盈利增长创下新纪录|date=29 May 1979|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Sin Chew Jit Poh (Singapore)|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
His daughter, Aw Ai Sim, is a veterinarian.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/straitstimes19890811-1.2.32.15.1|title=Angler's two-hour battle with man-sized marlin|date=11 August 1989|access-date=10 October 2017|work=The Straits Times|publisher=Singapore Press Holdings|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
Aw Cheng Chye's mum, Daw Saw, widow of Aw Boon Par, died in 1983.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/lhwb19831210-1.2.26.5|title=胡文豹夫人逝世|date=10 December 1983|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Lianhe Wanbao|publisher=Singapore News and Publications|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
Aw Cheng Chye is a Buddhist. He had a funeral in a Buddhist format. He was an honorary director of The Singapore Buddhist Lodge in the 1960s.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19600104-1.2.17.3|title=佛敎居士林董監聯席會議通過 設小組籌募度歲金 購置新林址決不動用前屆存款|date=4 January 1960|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/newspapers/Digitised/Article/nysp19620121-1.2.30.5|title=佛敎居士林選出第十四屆新職員並訂今晨舉行就職禮|date=21 January 1962|access-date=10 October 2017|work=Nanyang Siang Pau|publication-place=Singapore|language=Chinese|via=Singapore National Library}}</ref>
==Footnotes== {{reflist|group=nb}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}} * {{cite web|url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/printheritage/image.aspx?id=c809dfdc-6a58-4e63-83a7-1e190e1f2c5e|title=Portrait of Mr. Aw Cheng Chye, circa 1969|access-date=10 October 2017|publisher=Singapore National Library}}

{{Short description|House organ publication of Bell System}} {{italic title}} '''''Bell Laboratories Record'''''<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=September 1925|title=Bell Laboratories Record|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-Bell-Laboratories-Record/20s/Bell-Laboratories-Record-1925-09.pdf|journal=Bell Laboratories Record|volume=1|issue=1|pages=1-2 (in reader: 9-10)|via=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=CASSI Search Tool |url=http://cassi.cas.org/ |website=cassi.cas.org}}</ref> was a publication of the [[Bell System]] for many decades beginning in 1925. This [[house organ]] included descriptions of technologies created at many Bell System locations for basic research, devices, technologies, systems, and [[operations research]] relevant to telephone company, manufacturing, and government applications. The [[public relations]] department distributed the Record to all Bell System employees.{{Copyright violation|date=September 2018|sure=yes}} It was slimmer and less scholarly than ''[[Bell Labs Technical Journal]]''. On January 1, 1984 the magazine was transferred to [[AT&T Technologies]] and subsequently to [[Lucent Technologies]].
== See also == * [[TWX (magazine)|''TWX'' magazine]] * ''[[Bell Labs Technical Journal]]''
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{cite web |title=BELL LABORATORIES RECORD -The 'Phone Company' employee tech publication |url=https://www.americanradiohistory.com/Bell_Laboratories_Record_Issue_Key.htm |website=www.americanradiohistory.com}} 1925-1961

{{More citations needed|date=October 2009}} {{Infobox company | name = CIBC Mellon | logo = [[File:CIBC Mellon logo.PNG|268px|CIBC Mellon]] | type = [[Joint Venture]] | area_served = [[Canada]] | key_people = Steven R. Wolff, [[president (corporate title)|president]] and [[CEO]]
[[Daniel J. Smith]], [[chairman]][https://www.cibcmellon.com/en/newsroom/news/press-releases/cibc-mellon-names-daniel-j-smith-chair-of-cibc-mellons-boards-of-directors.jsp ] | industry = [[Financial Services]] | services = Asset Servicing | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | owner = 50% [[Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce|CIBC]]; 50% [[BNY Mellon]] | num_employees = 1,300 | divisions = CIBC Mellon Trust Company (CMTC) and CIBC Mellon Global Securities Services Company (CMGSS) | footnotes = Note that CMTC and CMGSS are in fact sister companies to each other, but operate seamlessly | foundation = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada ({{Start date|1996}}) | location_city = Toronto, Ontario | location_country = Canada | locations = 6 Offices (2009) | homepage = [http://www.cibcmellon.com/Contents/en_CA/English/Home/Home.html CIBCMellon.com] }} '''[[Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce|CIBC]] Mellon''' was founded in 1996 as a [[joint venture]] between the [[Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce]] (hereafter CIBC) and the [[Mellon Financial Corporation]] (now [[The Bank of New York Mellon]]) (hereafter Mellon) to offer asset servicing to institutional investors. While commonly known as CIBC Mellon, the company comprises two sister companies, '''CIBC Mellon [[Trust company|Trust Company]]''' and '''CIBC Mellon Global Securities Services Company''' (''Compagnie Trust CIBC Mellon'' and ''Société de services de titres mondiaux CIBC Mellon'' in French respectively). Based in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] CIBC Mellon offers asset servicing to corporate and institutional clients. On 16 February 2010, ''The Wall Street Journal'' reported that BNY Trust Co. of Canada would be acquiring the corporate trust assets of CIBC Mellon.{{Cite news | last = Van Hasselt | first = Caroline | title = Canada's BNY Trust to Buy CIBC Mellon's Corporate Trust Business: Sources | newspaper = Wall Street Journal | date = 16 February 2010 | url = https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20100216-708834.html?mod=WSJ_Deals_LEFTLatestHeadlines | accessdate = 16 February 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} On 28 July 2010 it was reported that [[Pacific Equity Partners]] would acquire CIBC Mellon Trust Company's issuer services business (stock transfer and employee share purchase plan).{{Cite web |url=http://www.cibcmellon.com/Contents/en_CA/English/NewsRoom/BulletinsReleases/2010/PR20100728.html# |title=CIBC Mellon and Pacific Equity Partners Sign Agreement for Purchase of Issuer Services Business |access-date=2010-07-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229040330/http://www.cibcmellon.com/Contents/en_CA/English/NewsRoom/BulletinsReleases/2010/PR20100728.html# |archive-date=2010-12-29 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In 2016, the company expanded into Mississauga, adding 150 roles.{{Cite web|url=http://www.newswire.ca/news-releases/cibc-mellon-expands-into-new-location-brings-150-jobs-to-mississauga-590002931.html|title=CIBC Mellon Expands into New Location, Brings 150+ Jobs to Mississauga|website=www.newswire.ca|language=en|access-date=2017-04-21}} ==Offices== CIBC Mellon's head office is in Toronto at 1 York Street. CIBC Mellon holds the lease from the fifth to tenth floor. There are satellite offices in Canada:{{Cite web|url=https://www.cibcmellon.com/en/contact/index.jsp|title=Contact|website=www.cibcmellon.com|language=EN|access-date=2017-04-21}} * [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]] - 6th floor [[Dome Tower]] * [[Halifax Regional Municipality|Halifax]], [[Nova Scotia]] * [[London, Ontario]] - 5th Floor, Richmond Court (150 Dufferin Avenue) * Mississauga, Ontario - 55 Standish Court, Suites 1200 and 1000 * [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]] - Suite 650, 1 1001 de Maisonneuve Blvd. West * [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] - Suite 1670 [[Oceanic Plaza]] (1066 West Hastings Street) ==History== CIBC Mellon was founded in 1996 after CIBC joined with Mellon Financial Corporation in a 50-50 joint venture named CIBC Mellon Global Securities Services (CMGSS).[https://www.nytimes.com/1996/02/13/business/international-business-bank-venture-in-canada.html?sec=&spon= New York Times, February 13, 1996] The following year, 1997, CIBC purchased a 50% stake in The R-M Trust Company from Mellon, which would become CMGSS's sister company, CIBC Mellon Trust Company (CMTC).Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, June 4, 1997, pp. C8; Mellon Sells Half of Unit CIBC Mellon acquired the Pension and Institutional Trust businesses from [[Canada Trust]] in 1997Toronto Star, May 8, 1997, pp. D7; Canada Trust Plans Sale and the global custody business from the [[Bank of Montreal]] in 1999.Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, May 18, 1999, pp. F1; Also in Business In 2002 CIBC Mellon acquired, from [[Toronto-Dominion Bank|TD Financial Group]], their third party investment fund custody business.http://www.efinancialnews.com/homepage/content/570779/printerfriendly/ ===Pacific Corporate Trust Company=== In 1998 it seemed that CIBC Mellon would be acquiring the Pacific Corporate Trust Company of [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]]. That deal eventually fell through, and it was subsequently acquired by [[Computershare|Computershare Limited]] in 2005.[http://www.alacrastore.com/storecontent/Thomson_M&A/CIBC_Mellon_Global_Securities_acquires_Pacific_Corporate_Trust_Co-777320040 CIBC Mellon Global Securities acquires Pacific Corporate Trust Co][http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-133229494.html Computershare Acquires Pacific Corporate Trust Company] ===Felcom Data Services acquisition=== On October 8, 2009, CIBC Mellon announced the acquisition of the unitholder recordkeeping and fund administration business of Felcom Data Services Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of [http://www.joviancapital.com Jovian Capital Corporation], for a purchase price of approximately C$4.2 million. CIBC Mellon indicated that they would offer employment to the majority of employees involved in the business lines acquired.{{Cite web |url=http://cibcmellon.com/Contents/en_CA/English/NewsRoom/BulletinsReleases/2009/PR20091008.html# |title=CIBC Mellon Press Release, October 8, 2009 |access-date=2009-10-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128223115/http://cibcmellon.com/Contents/en_CA/English/NewsRoom/BulletinsReleases/2009/PR20091008.html# |archive-date=2016-01-28 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ===Sale of issuer services business to Canadian Stock Transfer Company, Inc.=== On November 1, 2010, CIBC Mellon sold its issuer services business (stock transfer and employee share purchase plans) to Canadian Stock Transfer Company, Inc.[http://www.canstockta.com/CSTPressRelease.pdf Canadian Stock Transfer Company, Inc. Press Release, November 3, 2010] ==Structure== CIBC Mellon is a 50-50 [[joint venture]] between CIBC and BNY Mellon. CIBC Mellon operates independently from both of its "owners". While both CMTC and CMGSS physically occupy the same space, and in essence operate as one company, each has a separate [[board of directors]] which overlap the other. The executive management team, however, has authority over both companies. ===Leadership team=== The current leadership team (as of 2018) comprises the following:https://www.cibcmellon.com/en/who-we-are/leadership/index.jsp * [https://www.linkedin.com/in/stevenrwolff Steven R. Wolff], president and chief executive officer * Richard Anton, senior vice president and chief operations officer * Rob Ferguson, senior vice president, capital markets and shareholder relations * Claire Johnson, senior vice president, product initiatives * Karen Rowe, chief financial officer *Bill Graves, chief technology and data officer * Jeffrey Alexander, head of relationship management * Paul Cunliffe, head of corporate communications and marketing * Kelly Hastings, chief risk officer *Shane Kuros, head of relationship development, Canada * Tedford Mason, general counsel *Maple Tam, chief human resources officer *Catherine Thrasher, strategic client solutions and global risk solutions, CIBC Mellon and BNY Mellon ==== Past presidents and CEOs ==== * Douglas Nowers, 1996–1998 * [[Thomas C. MacMillan]], 1998–2009 * Thomas Monahan, 2009–2016{{Cite web|url=https://www.cibcmellon.com/en/newsroom/news/press-releases/cibc-mellon-names-steven-r-wolff-president-and-ceo.jsp|title=CIBC Mellon names Steven R Wolff President and CEO|website=www.cibcmellon.com|language=EN|access-date=2017-04-21}} ===Boards of directors=== The current board of directors (as of 2018) comprises the following:{{Cite web|url=https://www.cibcmellon.com/en/about-us/index.jsp#ir/boards-of-directors|title=About Us {{!}} CIBC Mellon|last=|first=|date=|website=www.cibcmellon.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-02-16}} * Daniel Smith, chairman, CIBC Mellon boards of directors and executive vice president, head of Americas asset servicing, BNY Mellon '''CIBC Mellon Global Securities Services Company''' *Anne-Marie Dunn, senior vice-president, talent acquisition and development, human resources, CIBC *John Ferren, senior vice-president and CFO, Canadian personal and small business banking, CIBC *Jeffrey Graham, partner, Borden Ladner Gervais LLP *Daniel Kramer, executive vice president, BNY Mellon Investment Services, and global head of client service delivery, BNY Mellon *Susan Rimmer, managing director and head, global corporate banking, CIBC World Markets Inc. *James Slater, executive vice president and global head of securities finance, BNY Mellon *Geoffrey Weiss, senior vice-president, deposits and product analytics, CIBC '''CIBC Mellon Trust Company ''' * Thaddeus Duchnowski, managing director, global client management, BNY Mellon *Anne-Marie Dunn, senior vice-president, talent acquisition and development, human resources, CIBC *John Ferren, senior vice-president and CFO, Canadian personal and small business banking, CIBC *David Gillespie, senior vice president of capital markets and wealth management operations, CIBC *Jeffrey Graham, partner, Borden Ladner Gervais LLP *Daniel Kramer, executive vice president, BNY Mellon Investment Services, and global head of client service delivery, BNY Mellon *Susan Rimmer, managing director and head, global corporate banking, CIBC World Markets Inc. *James Slater, executive vice president and global head of securities finance, BNY Mellon *Geoffrey Weiss, senior vice-president, deposits and product analytics, CIBC *Steven Wolff, president and CEO, CIBC Mellon ==== Chairmen ==== * Richard E Venn, until 2009 * [[Thomas C. MacMillan]], until 2012 *Samir Pandiri, until 2018 ==Securities investigations== CIBC Mellon has been the subject of two securities investigations. The first, in 1998, involved the now defunct Pay Pop Inc. The second, in 2004, involved the disclosure of custodial information to an outside source. ===Pay Pop Inc.=== In 1998, Alnoor Jiwan, a manager in CIBC Mellon's Vancouver office, was approached by Pay Pop Inc. and asked whether CIBC Mellon could issue Pay Pop Inc. shares without the required disclaimer which stated that the securities were not registered with the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|SEC]]. It was alleged by the SEC, in the subsequent investigation, that Mr Jiwan knew that the securities were not registered, but agreed to act as the transfer agent (in order to issue the stock certificates) in return for 820,000 Pay Pop shares. The SEC subsequently cited CIBC Mellon for acting as an unregistered broker and transfer agent, and for offering to sell unregistered securities in addition to alleging that the company was uncooperative in the investigation. Alnoor Jiwan was subsequently terminated for cause from CIBC Mellon, following the company's discovery of the transactions, and simultaneously ceasing all dealings with Pay Pop Inc.Toronto Star, February 17, 2005, p.D.4 CMTC agreed to pay a civil monetary penalty of US$5 million and disgorgement of $889,773 and prejudgment interest of $140,270. CMTC was permanently enjoined from prescribed violations of Securities Act Section 5, Exchange Act Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5, Exchange Act Section 15(a), Exchange Act Section 17A(c)(1), and from aiding and abetting future violations of Exchange Act Section 10(b) or Rule 10b-5. Payment was made on March 4, 2005. CMTC also consented, without admitting or denying the SEC complaint's allegations, to the entry of an SEC administrative order based on the final judgment on March 2, 2005. Pursuant to the order, CMTC was censured and agreed to an undertaking to engage an independent consultant to review its relevant businesses and procedures.[https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1277690/000127769011000002/xslFTAX01/primary_doc.xml TA1 dated January 12, 2011] ===Privacy breach=== In 2004, a long-term employee of CIBC Mellon was terminated, after it had been discovered that they had been disclosing institutional holdings in certain companies to unidentified parties in return for gifts. It was reported that the employee had received hockey and baseball tickets as well as up to $100 in cash for tips on big investors who owned specific stocks. The disclosures were discovered when a temporary worker received a request for data through an email. The subsequent investigation, which included reviewing phone and email records, discovered that the employee had been disclosing information for years.Toronto Star, December 9, 2004, p. C.1 ===Related party transactions with Enron=== In 2003, [[Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce|CIBC]] paid out $80 million in charges for complicity with [[Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce#Enron|its involvement]] with [[Enron]]. While the involvement was not related to CIBC Mellon, as CIBC is a majority stakeholder, it was required that it be reported on the TA-1 to the SEC. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{CIBC}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cibc Mellon}} [[Category:Trust companies of Canada]] [[Category:Companies based in Toronto]] [[Category:Joint ventures]] [[Category:Companies established in 1996]] [[Category:Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce]]

{{Infobox organization | name = Canadian Public Accountability Board | image = File:CPAB logo.png | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | abbreviation = CPAB | motto = | formation = {{start date and age|2003|04|14}} | founder = [[Canadian Securities Administrators]]
[[Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions]]
[[Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants]] | founding_location = | type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] | tax_id = 890500705RC0001 | registration_id = 4157826 | status = Not-for-profit corporation | purpose = National audit regulator with respect to public reporting issuers | headquarters = | location = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]] | membership = | membership_year = | leader_title = Chair | leader_name = Nicholas Le Pan | leader_title2 = Chief Executive Officer | leader_name2 = Carol Paradine | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | budget = $16,265,000 | budget_year = 2015 | revenue = $16,139,000 | revenue_year = 2014 | disbursements = | expenses = $16,914,000 | expenses_year = 2014 | endowment = | staff = | staff_year = | volunteers = | volunteers_year = | slogan = World class audit regulation | mission = Effective regulation | website = {{URL|www.cpab-ccrc.ca}} | remarks = | formerly = | footnotes = }} The '''Canadian Public Accountability Board''' ("CPAB") ({{lang-fr|Conseil canadien sur la reddition de comptes}}) is a national body organized by the [[Canadian Securities Administrators]] ("CSA") which oversees Canadian accounting firms performing [[auditing]] work. ==Formation== The CPAB was formed in 2003, as part of Canada's response to the occurrence of [[accounting scandals]] that were happening worldwide, such as at [[Enron scandal|Enron]] and [[Worldcom]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/piecemeal-system-hampers-watchdog/article547735/ |first=Tara |last=Perkins |title=Piecemeal system hampers watchdog| newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] |date=August 18, 2008 |accessdate=2008-08-20 }} It was different in approach from the ''[[Sarbanes-Oxley Act]]''{{USStatute|107|204|116|745|2002|07|30}} adopted in the [[United States]]. In 2016, its CEO stated that the Board "encourages a more holistic approach to better understand the root causes of lapses in audit quality," in contrast to that taken by the US [[Public Company Accounting Oversight Board]].{{cite news |last= Jeffrey|first= Gundi|date= February 2016|title= Canadian board has concerns over new U.S. rules|url= http://thebottomlinenews.ca/articles/817|newspaper= The Bottom Line|location= Toronto}} The CSA have specified that a "reporting issuer" (ie, a publicly traded company) must have its financial statements audited by a "participating audit firm," being one that has entered into a participation agreement with the CPAB which has not been terminated.NI 52-108, s. 2 Its authority is reinforced through legislation passed at the provincial level,{{cite web |url= http://www.cpab-ccrc.ca/en/About/Legislation/Pages/default.aspx|title= Legislation|author= |date= |website= |publisher= CPAB}} of which [[Ontario]] has passed the most extensive example.{{Cite canlaw|short title =Canadian Public Accountability Board Act (Ontario)|abbr =S.O.|year =2006|chapter = 33|schedule= D|link= https://www.ontario.ca/laws/statute/06c33}} ==Scope== 164 Canadian and 133 foreign firms have entered into participation agreements with the CPAB. These firms audit approximately 4,000 reporting issuers and 3,000 investment funds.{{cite web |url= http://www.cpab-ccrc.ca/en/Stakeholder/AuditFirms/Pages/default.aspx|title= Audit Firms|author= |date= |publisher= CPAB}} Of these firms, fourteen are inspected annually, of which the [[Big Four (audit firms)|Big Four]] account for 98% of total market capitalization on Canadian markets, and the other 10 large firms account for a further 1.5%. The other firms are subject to inspection on a triennial basis. ==Governance== The CPAB has two governing bodies. The Council of Governors consists of six members, who are the [[Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions|Superintendent of Financial Institutions]], the Chair of the [[Ontario Securities Commission]], the Chair of the ''[[Autorité des marchés financiers (Québec)|Autorité des marchés financiers]]'', the Chair of the [[Canadian Securities Administrators]],{{efn|when the Chair of the CSA is already a Chair of the OSC or AMF, the CSA will select an alternative Governor}} a fifth Governor selected by the CSA, and a sixth Governor selected by the other five who is a [[public accountant]] that has audit oversight regulatory experience.CPAB By-laws, Article 8 In turn, the Council appoints the Board of Directors, who are responsible for supervising the activities of the organization.CPAB By-laws, Article 3 ==Deficiencies and controversies== A 2007-8 review by CPAB of financial statements audited by the [[Big Six auditors|Big Six]] firms revealed that of 130 audit files examined, 11 were found to have deficiencies. In 2011, the Board raised concerns that auditors only [[Emotion|reacted]] when issues were raised by its inspectors, and that they were not taking [[proactive]] measures to improve the quality of their work.{{cite news |last= McFarland|first= Janet|date= April 18, 2011|title= Audit quality at risk in Canada, regulator warns |url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/audit-quality-at-risk-in-canada-regulator-warns/article547732/|newspaper= [[The Globe and Mail]] }} The report also noted that the same findings were being noted year after year, and that the majority of deficiencies related to basic audit procedures.{{cite news |last= Tedesco|first= Theresa|date= April 4, 2012|title= Watchdog still finds 'deficiencies' in high-risk audits in Canada|url= http://business.financialpost.com/news/fp-street/watchdog-still-finds-deficiencies-in-high-risk-audits-in-canada|newspaper= [[The Financial Post]]|location= |access-date= }} Little progress was seen to have occurred in 2012,{{cite news |last= McFarland|first= Janet|date= April 3, 2012|title= Audit firms show little progress, weaknesses persist: report|url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/audit-firms-show-little-progress-weaknesses-persist-report/article4097397/|newspaper= [[The Globe and Mail]] }} and a low level of professional [[skepticism]] was still seen as a major issue in 2013.{{cite news |last= McFarland|first= Janet|date= April 4, 2013|title= Audits improving but more 'professional skepticism' needed: Watchdog|url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/audits-improving-but-more-professional-skepticism-needed-watchdog/article10764697/|newspaper= [[The Globe and Mail]] }} In 2012, CPAB released a review it conducted of work done by Canadian audit firms with Chinese clients. It found flaws in 12 of the 24 companies examined, and barred one auditor from doing such work until it upgraded its procedures.{{cite news |last= McFarland|first= Janet|date= February 21, 2012|title= Canadian audits of China firms had major gaps: regulator |url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-investor/canadian-audits-of-china-firms-had-major-gaps-regulator/article547857/|newspaper= [[The Globe and Mail]] }} This was significant, as, in 2011, 56 companies from China and other parts of Asia were listed on the [[TSX]] or [[TSX Venture Exchange]], many getting their listings through [[reverse takeover]]s of dormant [[shell corporation]]s, and [[Sino-Forest Corporation]] had collapsed in mid-year after irregularities were found in its financial results. In 2014, the Board reported that it was still experiencing difficulties in being able to review foreign operations of some Canadian-based companies.{{cite news |last= McFarland|first= Janet|date= March 31, 2014|title= Audit firm regulator says it can't vouch for work outside Canada|url= https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/audit-firm-regulator-says-it-cant-vouch-for-work-outside-canada/article17739581/|newspaper= [[The Globe and Mail]] }} Because of irregularities such as those occurring at [[Sino-Forest]], the CSA issued proposals in 2013 to require mandatory notification of certain events to reporting issuers and regulatory authorities,{{cite news |last= Schecter|first= Barbara|date= October 17, 2013|title= Canadian securities regulators to ramp up oversight of auditors|url= http://business.financialpost.com/news/fp-street/canadian-securities-regulators-to-ramp-up-oversight-of-auditors|newspaper= [[The Financial Post]]|location= |access-date= }} which were subsequently adopted in 2014.NI 52-108, ss. 3-4 In November 2015, the Board reported that the incidence of significant findings in files examined was increasing,{{sfn|CPAB|2015a|p=3}} and that the most prominent audit issues concerned the execution of audit fundamentals and the understanding of a client's business processes that are relevant to financial reporting.{{sfn|CPAB|2015a|pp=4-5}} A report earlier that year stated that the incidence of deficiencies observed appeared to be declining in files concerning the Big Four and other national/network firms,{{sfn|CPAB|2015b|p=4}} but was increasing in files concerning regional firms.{{sfn|CPAB|2015b|p=5}} ==Further reading== * {{cite web |url= http://www.cpab-ccrc.ca/Documents/Topics/rules%20and%20agreements/rule_52-108-aud-oversight.pdf|title= '''Cummings Research Park''', located primarily in the city of [[Huntsville, Alabama]] is the second largest research park in the country and the fourth largest in the world. It is one of the world’s leading science and technology business parks, with a mixture of Fortune 500 companies, local and international high-tech enterprises, U.S. space and defense agencies, thriving business incubators and competitive higher-education institutions. CRP is the home of nearly 300 companies, more than 26,000 employees and 12,500 students. The Park's major industries are aerospace, defense, engineering, biotechnology, advanced manufacturing, software development, information technology and cyber security.
Cummings Research Park was voted as the Most Outstanding Science Park in the World in 1997 by the Association of University Research Parks and in 2017 The Park was presented with the Developing Communities of Innovation award.<ref>[http://www.huntsvillealabamausa.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=169&Itemid=332 Huntsville Chamber of Commerce - CRP History]</ref>
==History ==
In 1961, [[Milton K. Cummings]], then president of [[Teledyne Brown Engineering|Brown Engineering Company]], and Joseph C. Moquin, his later successor, selected a tract of undeveloped land on the western edge of Huntsville for building a new headquarters. Located adjacent to land that had recently been acquired by the [[University of Alabama]] for developing a Huntsville Branch and within a few miles of major Army and NASA development centers on [[Redstone Arsenal]], this area was ideal for establishing a high-technology research park.
Cummings and Moquin, with the support of rocket pioneer [[Wernher von Braun]], proposed that the City of Huntsville zone the area as a research park district. In 1962, the City established this zoning, with 3,000 acres of land officially designated Huntsville Research Park.
Brown Engineering (later [[Teledyne Technologies#Companies|Teledyne Brown Engineering]]) was the first to build in the park, opening its campus the inaugural year. As America rushed into the space race, other companies quickly followed; these included giant national firms such as [[Lockheed Martin|Lockheed]], [[Northrop Grumman|Northrop]], and [[IBM]], smaller outside firms wanting to open Huntsville operations, and a number of newly organized local enterprises.
In parallel with the growth of industry occupants, the adjacent academic campus also matured; in 1970, this became the [[University of Alabama in Huntsville]] (UAH). The UAH Foundation owned a large portion of land in the research park district, and served as a major promoter of development. When Milton Cummings died in 1973, the district was renamed the Cummings Research Park (CRP). By the end of the 1970s, the development of what is now known as CRP East was nearing completion.
In 1982, the second major phase of CRP was launched with the planned development of CRP West. A substantial new parcel of land, exceeding 800 acres, was purchased and a master plan was established by the City of Huntsville. This new phase strengthened the development restrictions on the park, rivaling, and in many instances exceeding, the quality of planned research and development parks anywhere in the world. The City of Huntsville has continued to acquire land for future growth of CRP, and it is now approaching 4,000 acres.
