revision.text:
{{about|the street in San Francisco}} {{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} [[Image:Montgomery Street from Telegraph Hill, San Francisco.jpg|thumb|225px|Looking south down Montgomery Street from Telegraph Hill through the Financial District]]
'''Montgomery Street''' is a north-south thoroughfare in [[San Francisco]], [[California]], in the United States.
It runs about 16 blocks from the [[Telegraph Hill, San Francisco|Telegraph Hill]] neighborhood south through downtown, terminating at [[Market Street (San Francisco)|Market Street]]. South of [[Columbus Avenue (San Francisco)|Columbus Avenue]], Montgomery Street runs through the heart of San Francisco's [[Financial District, San Francisco|Financial District]] and contains one of the highest concentrations of financial activity, investment business, and venture capital in the [[United States]] and the world. For this reason, it is known as "the [[Wall Street of the West]]".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.streetcar.org/f-line.html|title=F-Market & Wharves Streetcar Line – Market Street Railway|accessdate=July 31, 2010}}</ref><ref name="GSA">{{cite book|last=Prentice|first=Carol S.|title=1906 San Francisco earthquake centennial field guides|year=2006|publisher=Geological Society of America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CwchZE54dWYC&pg=PA17 |accessdate=July 31, 2010|page=17|chapter=Walk 3:Montgomery Street to Jackson Square}}</ref> South of Market Street, the street continues as [[New Montgomery Street]] for two more blocks to terminate at Howard Street in the [[South of Market, San Francisco, California|SOMA]] district.
==History== [[Image:Montgomerystreetsf.jpg|thumb|225px|Looking north from Market Street up Montgomery Street towards the [[Transamerica Pyramid]]. In the foreground is the flagship branch of [[Wells Fargo Bank]].]]
In the 1830s, the land which is now Montgomery Street lay at the edge of [[San Francisco Bay]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfmuseum.org/hist1/early.html|title=San Francisco – Before the Gold Rush – 1847|accessdate=July 31, 2010}}</ref><ref name=OHP>{{Cite web|url=http://ohp.parks.ca.gov/default.asp?page_id=21482|title=Office of Historic Preservation: San Francisco|accessdate=July 31, 2010}}</ref> Intense [[land speculation]] during the [[California Gold Rush|Gold Rush]] created a demand for more usable land in the rapidly growing city, and sandy bluffs near the waterfront were leveled and the shallows filled with sand (and the ruins of many ships) to make new building lots. Between 1849 and 1852, the waterfront advanced about four blocks.<ref>[[:File:1853 U.S.C.S. Map of San Francisco, California ^ Vicinity - Geographicus - SanFrancisco3-uscs-1853.jpg|City of San Francisco and its Vicinity California (Map, 1853)]]</ref> At present, Montgomery Street is about seven blocks from the water.
The corner of Montgomery and Clay is where [[John B. Montgomery]] landed when he came to hoist the [[Flag of the United States|U.S. flag]] after the [[Bear Flag Revolt]] of 1846. In 1853 the [[Montgomery Block]], a center of early San Francisco law and literature, was built at 600 Montgomery, on land currently occupied by the [[Transamerica Pyramid]].<ref name=OHP />
==Offices== [[Image:Historic American Buildings Survey A. J. Wittlock, Photographer March 1940 TELEGRAPH HILL AND MONTGOMERY STREET HOUSES - Telegraph Hill (House), 1301 Montgomery Street, San HABS CAL,38-SANFRA,126-1.tif|thumb|Montgomery Street building, 1940]] Many banks and financial-services companies have had offices in the buildings on or near Montgomery Street, especially between Market Street and Sacramento Street: * The world headquarters of [[Wells Fargo]] are at 420 Montgomery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://yahoo.brand.edgar-online.com/displayfilinginfo.aspx?FilingID=7376060-1063-6229&type=sect&dcn=0001193125-10-167482|accessdate=July 31, 2010|title=EDGAR Online: Wells Fargo & Co/MN (WFC) – 8-K – 7/27/2010}}</ref> * [[555 California Street]], between [[Kearny Street|Kearny]] and Montgomery, served as [[Bank of America]]'s world headquarters prior to its merger with [[NationsBank]] and was (from 1969 to 2005) officially called the Bank of America Building.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.emporis.com/application/?nav=building&lng=3&id=118721|title=555 California St., San Francisco, CA|accessdate=July 31, 2010}}</ref> * The [[Transamerica Pyramid]] (600 Montgomery, at Columbus Avenue) was the headquarters of [[Transamerica Corporation]] and still appears in the company's logo.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.emporis.com/application/?nav=building&lng=3&id=118715|title=Transamerica Pyramid|accessdate=July 31, 2010}}</ref> * [[Melvin Belli]], lawyer known as "The King of Torts", had his offices at the ''Belli Building'' at 722-724 Montgomery St.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.coastnews.com/sf/belli.htm|title= When Renovation Meets Litigation -- And the Trash Piles Up|author= Crovo, Lisa|date= |work= |publisher= San Francisco Coastnews|accessdate= 12 September 2013}}</ref> Belli used to raise a [[Jolly Roger]] and fire a cannon every time he won a case.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.sfweekly.com/2000-04-12/news/battle-belli/|title= Battle Belli|author= Davis, Lisa|date= 12 April 2000|work= |publisher= [[San Francisco Weekly]]|accessdate= 12 September 2013}}</ref> * [[Bank of the West]] is headquartered at [[180 Montgomery Street]].
==High-rises== Notable high-rises and skyscrapers along Montgomery Street in the Financial District:
*[[44 Montgomery]] *[[Hunter-Dulin Building]] (111 Sutter at Montgomery) *[[100 Montgomery Street]] *[[101 Montgomery]] *[[180 Montgomery Street]] *[[Russ Building]] (235 Montgomery) *[[Commercial Union Assurance Building]] (315 Montgomery) *[[456 Montgomery Plaza]] *[[505 Montgomery Street]] *[[Transamerica Pyramid]] (600 Montgomery) A building bearing the name of [[One Montgomery Tower]] is located at the intersection of [[Post Street|Post]] and [[Kearny Street|Kearny]] streets, behind the Wells Fargo flagship branch and [[Crocker Galleria]].
==Public transit== Montgomery Street is served by the [[Bay Area Rapid Transit|BART]] and [[Muni Metro]] [[Montgomery Street Station]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bart.gov/stations/mont/index.aspx|accessdate=July 31, 2010|title=BART – Montgomery St.}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox newspaper | name = Napi Gazdaság | logo = | image = | caption = | type =[[Daily newspaper]] | format = | owners = Századvég Gazdaságkutató | founder = | publisher = | editor = | chiefeditor = György Barcza | assoceditor = | maneditor = Péter Keresztesi | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = 17 September 1991 | political = | language =[[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] | ceased publication = 31 August 2015 | headquarters = [[Budapest]] | circulation = | sister newspapers = | ISSN = | oclc = | website = }}
'''''Napi Gazdaság''''' (meaning ''Daily Business'' in English)<ref>{{cite web|title=Napi.hu|url=http://www.publicitas.com/de/germany/medienangebot/factsheet/?PARAM1=QT0NB1|work=Publicitas|accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref> was a [[Budapest]]-based [[daily newspaper]] published in [[Hungary]] from 1991 to 2015. The daily focused on financial and business news. It was succeeded by ''[[Magyar Idők]]'', a conservative political daily on 1 September 2015.<ref name=mandiner>{{cite web|title=Keddtől Magyar Idők néven jelenik meg a Napi Gazdaság|url=http://media.mandiner.hu/cikk/20150901_keddtol_magyar_idok_neven_jelenik_meg_a_napi_gazdasag|work=mandiner.hu|accessdate=30 September 2015|date=1 September 2015}}</ref>
==History and profile== ''Napi Gazdaság'' was based in Budapest.<ref>[http://www.hotnewspapers.com/hungary-newspapers/napi-gazdasag/2324/ Hungary Newspapers] ''Hotnewspapers'' Retrieved 6 December 2013.</ref><ref name=esi/> In the late 1990s the owner of the daily bankrupted and a group of young investors bought it.<ref name=rita99/> During this period the paper was independent and covered [[Investigative journalism|investigative reports]].<ref name=rita99/> The Central European Media and Publishing Co. (CEMP) acquired 50% of the daily in 2007.<ref>[http://cemp.hu/download/53/CEMP_presentation_090421_en.pdf CEMP presentation] CEMP. Retrieved 6 December 2013.</ref> It was owned by CEMP until August 2013 when it was sold to the [[think tank]] and research center [[Századvég|Századvég Economic Research Inc.]] (Századvég Gazdaságkutató in Hungarian).<ref name=bbj>{{cite news|author=Krisztián Kummer|title=Napi Gazdaság: The think tank newspaper|url=http://www.bbj.hu/business/napi-gazdasag-the-think-tank-newspaper_68762|accessdate=6 December 2013|work=Budapest Business Journal|date=9 September 2013}}</ref><ref name=hmm>{{cite web|title=Fidesz-linked firm buys national economic daily|url=http://mediamonitor.ceu.hu/2013/08/fidesz-linked-firm-buys-national-economic-daily/|work=Hungarian Media Monitor|accessdate=6 December 2013|date=13 August 2013}}</ref> The think tank is linked to [[Fidesz]], a conservative political party.<ref name=hmm/> The website of the daily, Napi.hu, remained in possession of CEMP.<ref name=bb/> The last [[editor-in-chief]] of the daily was György Barcza and its managing director was Péter Keresztesi.<ref name=bbj/>
''Napi Gazdaság'' provided mostly financial news and was one of two business newspapers in the country.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hungary|url=https://reutersinstitute.politics.ox.ac.uk/fileadmin/documents/Media_Landscapes/Hungary.pdf|work=Reuters Institute|accessdate=6 December 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131215002245/https://reutersinstitute.politics.ox.ac.uk/fileadmin/documents/Media_Landscapes/Hungary.pdf|archivedate=15 December 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name=esi>{{cite web|title=Communicating Europe: Hungary Manual|url=http://www.esiweb.org/pdf/enlargement_debates_manual_hungary.pdf|work=European Stability Initiative|accessdate=26 November 2014|date=December 2010}}</ref> The other business newspaper in the country is ''[[Világgazdaság]]''.<ref name=esi/>
The daily occasionally published supplements one of which was about Polish economy and in Polish.<ref>{{cite web|title=Polish supplement|url=http://www.bisztrai.com/lang/en/polska-dodatek-do-wegierskiego-dziennika-gospodarczego-napi-gazdasagslengyelorszag-a-napi-gazdasag-mellekletes/|work=Kislow|accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref> On 31 August 2015 the paper ceased publication.<ref name=mandiner/>
==Circulation== The 1998 circulation of ''Napi Gazdaság'' was 14,000 copies.<ref name=ecpr>{{cite web|author1=Marina Popescu|author2=Gábor Tóka|title=Campaign Effects in the 1994 and 1998 Parliamentary Elections in Hungary|url=http://ecpr.eu/Filestore/PaperProposal/07edc96c-b442-44d1-a6bc-decf66f013e2.pdf|work=European Consortium for Political Research|accessdate=26 November 2014|date=April 2000}}</ref> It was 15,000 copies in 1999.<ref name=rita99>{{cite journal|author1=Rita M. Csapo-Sweet|author2=Ildiko Kaposi|title=Mass Media in Post-Communist Hungary|journal=International Communications Bulletin|date=Spring 1999|volume=34|issue=1-2|url=http://userpages.umbc.edu/~hasegawa/aejmc-icd/spring99/mediainhungary.html|accessdate=27 December 2014}}</ref> The audited readership per day was 33,000 in 2012.<ref name=napi>{{cite web|title=Media offer 2013|url=http://www.napi.hu/download/napi_gazdasag_print_media_offer_2013.pdf|work=Napi|accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref>
==Controversy== In November 2013, English language news website specializing in current events taking place in Hungary, [[The Budapest Beacon]], reported that both ''Napi Gazdaság'''s daily edition and its website were fined by the [[National Bank of Hungary]] for illegally manipulating the market.<ref name=bb>{{cite news|author=Richard Field|title=Hungarian Central Bank fines newspaper for "influencing the market in a prohibited manner"|url=http://budapestbeacon.com/news-in-brief/hungarian-central-bank-fines-newspaper-for-influencing-the-market-in-a-prohibited-manner/|accessdate=6 December 2013|work=The Budapest Beacon|date=25 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=National Bank of Hungary Fined Napi Gazdaság and Napi.hu for Illegal Market Manipulation|url=http://www.xpatloop.com/news/75124|accessdate=6 December 2013|work=XpatLoop|date=27 November 2013}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of newspapers in Hungary]]
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}

{{third-party|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox non-profit | name = National Entrepreneurship Network(NEN) | image = National_Entrepreneurship_Network(NEN)_Logo.png | image_size = 250px | caption = | founder = [[Romesh Wadhwani]]{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ryanmac/2012/09/28/new-giving-pledge-member-romesh-wadhwani-promotes-entrepreneurship//|title=New Giving Pledge Member Romesh Wadhwani Promotes Entrepreneurship|publisher=Forbes|date=2012-09-28 |accessdate=2014-11-20}} | type = [[Entrepreneurship ecosystem]] | tax_id = | registration_id = | founded_date = 2003 | location = [[Bengaluru]] & [[Palo Alto]] | coordinates = | origins = India | key_people = Ajay Kela,
Chief Executive Officer{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/fostering-entrepreneurship-a-long-way-to-go/article6349349.ece/|title=Fostering entrepreneurship, a long way to go|publisher=The Hindu |date=2014-08-25 |accessdate=2014-11-17}} | area_served = Global | products = | services = [[Capacity building]], [[Inclusive entrepreneurship]] | focus = [[Entrepreneurship]] | mission = | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = over 70,000 | subsid = | owner = [[Wadhwani Foundation]] | motto = | former name = | homepage = {{Official website|http://nenglobal.org}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''National Entrepreneurship Network''' or '''NEN'''[http://www.thehindu.com/news/national/fostering-entrepreneurship-a-long-way-to-go/article6349349.ece]. The Hindu(accessed 17 November 2014). is a [[community]] dedicated to fostering [[entrepreneurship]]. Services focus on providing [[Capacity Building|Institutional Capacity Building]], Entrepreneur support, Entrepreneurial eco-system & National platforms. Based on an idea by [[Romesh Wadhwani]], the goal of the community is to enable new and future entrepreneurs to access events and resources, share ideas and content, organize and market activities, and forge relationships across India and the world. The offices are located in [[Bangalore]] & [[Palo Alto]]. ==History of NEN== National Entrepreneurship Network(NEN) was launched in 2003, as a non-profit initiative of the [[Wadhwani Foundation]]. It was co-founded with [[Indian Institute of Technology Bombay|IIT Mumbai]], [[Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad|IIM Ahmedabad]], [[Birla Institute of Technology and Science|BITS Pilani]], [[S. P. Jain Institute of Management and Research|SPJIMR Mumbai]] and [[Institute of Bioinformatics and Applied Biotechnology (IBAB)|IBAB Bengaluru]]{{cite web|url=http://ecell.in/the-entrepreneurship-cell/associates//|title=Our Partner Organizations|publisher=ECell IIT Mumbai|accessdate=2014-11-20}} ==See also== * [[Business incubator]] * [[Business cluster]] * [[Creative entrepreneurship]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Further reading == * Robert A. Baron (2010). ''Entrepreneurship: An Evidence-based Guide'', [[Edward Elgar Publishing]], 229 pages. {{ISBN|1781000387}} * Kharas, Homi; Makino, Koji; and Woojin Jung (2011). ''Catalyzing Development: A New Vision for Aid'', [[Brookings Institution Press]], 305 pages. {{ISBN|978-0815721345}} * Bornstein, David; and Susan Davis (2010). ''Social Entrepreneurship: What Everyone Needs to Know'', [[Oxford University Press]], 147 pages. {{ISBN|978-0195396331}} ==External links== * [http://nenglobal.org/ Official website] [[Category:Community building]] [[Category:Professional networks]] [[Category:Entrepreneurship organizations]] [[Category:Entrepreneurship in India]] [[Category:2003 establishments in India]] {{Org-stub}}

{{Infobox person |name = Petr Olegovich Aven |image = Petr_Aven,_Speaking_in_New_York.jpg |caption = Petr Aven speaking in New York, 2015 |birth_date = {{b-da|March 16, 1955}} |birth_place = [[Moscow]], [[Russian SFSR|Russia]] |known_for = [[Alfa-Bank]] |alma_mater = |occupation = International businessman |spouse = |children = two |education = [[Moscow State University]] |nationality = {{flag|RU|name=Russian}} |net worth = [[United States dollar|US$]]4.6 [[1,000,000,000 (number)|billion]]
(August 2018)[https://www.forbes.com/profile/pyotr-aven/ Forbes: The World's Billionaires - Pyotr Aven] March 2014}} '''Petr Olegovich Aven''' (also transliterated Pyotr Aven; {{lang-ru|Пëтр Олегович Авен}}; born March 16, 1955) is an International businessman, economist and politician. He heads [[Alfa-Bank]], Russia's largest commercial bank. He is a member of the Board of Directors at [[LetterOne|LetterOne Group]]. L1 Group was established in 2013 to invest in international projects in energy, telecommunications and technology. Petr Aven is also the author of some scientific papers and articles on economic and trade issues and is quoted in the financial and trade press on matters related to the Russian economy and trade policy. In 2015 Petr Aven and [[Alfred Kokh]] published ''Gaidar’s Revolution: The Inside Account of the Economic Transformation of Russia'', drawing on their experience of the Russian Government and the former First Minister for the Economy, [[Yegor Gaidar]].{{cite web|title=Exclusive "No Tie" Interview With Head Of The Alfa Banking Holding, Petr Aven On Business, Childhood And Friends|url=http://jewishbusinessnews.com/2015/11/19/exclusive-no-tie-interview-with-alfa-banks-president-peter-aven-on-business-childhood-and-friends/}} In his review of the book, John Lloyd of the [[Financial Times]] called it “an illuminating study of the reformers who sought to revive Russia’s post- Soviet economy.”{{cite web|title=‘Gaidar’s Revolution’, by Petr Aven and Alfred Kokh|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/df3078c0-1f3d-11e5-ab0f-6bb9974f25d0.html#axzz3k7Eys8kd}} In 2015 he was named number 301 in the richest people in the world, with a worth of around $5.1 billion.{{Cite web|title = The Forbes World's Billionaires list is the definitive list of the world's wealthiest people, profiling and ranking billionaires from 70 countries by their estimated net worth.|url = https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/list/#version:static_country:Russia|website = Forbes|accessdate = 2015-12-01}} ==Early life and education== Born in Moscow, his father, professor of computer science Oleg Aven ({{lang-ru|Олег Иванович Авен}}), was half [[Latvian people|Latvian]] and half [[Russians|Russian]][http://interpretive.ru/dictionary/1086/word/aven-petr-olegovich National Historical Encyclopedia, Biography of P. O. Aven by N. Zenkovich], 2004[http://www.lechaim.ru/ARHIV/217/lkl.htm Interview with P. Aven] May, 2010 and his mother was from a [[Russian Jewish|Jewish]] family.[http://www.jpost.com/Jewish-World/Jewish-Features/The-worlds-50-Richest-Jews-41-50 Jerusalem Post: "The world's 50 Richest Jews: 41-50"] September 7, 2010 His paternal grandfather Janis Aven or Jānis Avens [[:lv:Jānis Avens|(lv)]] was a [[Latvian riflemen|Latvian rifleman]]. Petr Aven graduated from [[Moscow State University]] in 1977 and holds a PhD in Economics (1980). ==Career== After graduation from university, Aven was a senior researcher at the All-Union Institute for Systems Studies at the [[USSR]] Academy of Sciences and then spent time at the [[International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis]] in [[Laxenburg]], [[Austria]] (1989–1991). Concerning Russian economic reform in the early 1990s, he and other reformer colleagues had consulted with foreign academics by 1990 on trying to find a new system. When [[Boris Yeltsin]] became president, he appointed Aven with the task of making the ruble convertible and finding a solution to foreign debt.https://news.yale.edu/2017/11/13/aven-offers-inside-account-making-modern-russia Aven went on to become the Minister of Foreign Economic Relations for the Russian Federation (1991–1992), serving as [[Russia]]'s representative to the [[G7|Group of Seven]] and conducting a number of high-level trade and economic missions to Western capitals. In 1993 he joined the [[Democratic Choice of Russia|Russia's Choice]] movement and was a candidate for State Duma. In October 1994, Aven met [[Alfa Group]]'s [[Mikhail Fridman]], and soon became an Alfa Bank shareholder serving as a member of the Supervisory Board of the Alfa Group Consortium. From 1994 until June 2011, he served as the President of [[Alfa-Bank]] Russia. Currently Aven is a Member of the Board of Directors and Chairman of the Board of Directors of ABH Holdings S.A.[http://alfabank.com/governance/board/aven/ Petr Aven profile.] Alfa-Bank Board of Directors. Retrieved 16 November 2011. Aven is also Chairman of the Board of Directors at AlfaStrakhovanie Group, Co-Chairman of the Board of Directors of [[CTC Media]], Inc.https://people.forbes.com/profile/peter-aven/24447 Petr Aven profile. Forbes. In 2012, the Alfa Group together with [[Viktor Vekselberg]] of [[Renova Group]] and [[Leonard Blavatnik]] of [[Access Industries]] sold their aggregate 50% stake in [[TNK-BP]] to state-owned [[Rosneft]] for $28 billion. In 2013, Aven joined the Board of LetterOne Group, an international investment business founded by [[Mikhail Fridman]] and focused on the [[telecoms]], [[technology]] and [[Energy industry|energy sectors]]. The L1 Group owns companies – and has equity investments in companies – with operations in 32 countries around the world. LetterOne acquired assets from German utility business E. ON in October 2015, in a deal worth $1.6bn, that saw the Luxembourg-based group gain Norwegian oil and gas resources.{{cite news|title=E.ON agrees 1 billion pound sale of North Sea assets to Fridman|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2015/10/14/uk-northsea-m-a-e-on-idUKKCN0S80TV20151014|agency=Reuters}} In the following month, LetterOne also announced their intention to deal with Brazilian telecoms company Oi SA, and boost their presence in the mobile phone sector there.{{cite news|title=Fridman Offers $4 Billion to Merge Brazil Carriers Oi, Tim|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-10-26/oi-may-get-up-to-4-billion-from-letter-one-in-tim-deal|publisher=Bloomberg}} ==Legal== In 2005, a [[United States district court]] in Washington, D.C. dismissed a 2000 libel suit by Aven and fellow Alfa Bank owner [[Mikhail Fridman]] against the [[Center for Public Integrity]] over an online article which included a suggestion that they had been involved in drug-running and organized crime; the [[United States federal judge|federal judge]] ruled that there was no evidence of [[actual malice]] on the part of the publication and that Fridman and Aven were [[public figure|limited public figures]] regarding the public controversy involving corruption in post-Soviet Russia.{{cite news|last1=Gerstein|first1=Josh|title=3 Russians named in Trump dossier sue Fusion GPS for libel|url=https://www.politico.com/blogs/under-the-radar/2017/10/04/trump-dossier-fusion-gps-russians-lawsuit-fridman-aven-khan-243461|accessdate=29 March 2018|work=[[Politico]]|date=4 October 2017}}{{cite web|title=Libel case over mafia-Halliburton link dismissed|url=https://www.rcfp.org/browse-media-law-resources/news/libel-case-over-mafia-halliburton-link-dismissed|website=[[Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press]]|accessdate=29 March 2018|date=4 October 2005}}{{cite news|title=Alfa Loses Libel Suit in U.S. Court|url=http://old.themoscowtimes.com/sitemap/free/2005/9/article/alfa-loses-libel-suit-in-us-court/209607.html|accessdate=29 March 2018|work=[[The Moscow Times]]|date=29 September 2005}}{{cite book|last1=Fortescue|first1=Stephen|title=Russia's Oil Barons and Metal Magnates: Oligarchs and the State in Transition|date=2006|publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|page=69|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kr-JDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA69}} In May 2017 Aven, along with fellow Alfa Bank owners [[Mikhail Fridman]] and [[German Khan]], filed a defamation lawsuit against ''[[BuzzFeed]]'' for publishing the unverified [[Donald Trump–Russia dossier]],{{cite news|last1=Porter|first1=Tom|title=Russian Bankers Sue BuzzFeed Over Publication Of Unverified Trump Dossier|url=http://www.newsweek.com/alfa-bank-buzzfeed-trump-dossier-616763|accessdate=28 May 2017|work=[[Newsweek]]|date=27 May 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Gerstein|first1=Josh|title=Russian bank owners sue BuzzFeed over Trump dossier publication|url=http://www.politico.com/blogs/under-the-radar/2017/05/26/trump-dossier-russian-bank-owners-sue-buzzfeed-238876|accessdate=28 May 2017|work=[[Politico]]|date=26 May 2017}}{{cite web|title=Mikhail Fridman, Petr Aven, and German Khan v. Buzzfeed, Inc. - Summons and Complaint|url=https://www.politico.com/f/?id=0000015c-46e1-dd50-abfd-dffd3af20001|date=May 26, 2018|access-date=August 20, 2018|via=[[Politico]]|format=PDF}} which alleges financial ties and collusion between Putin, Trump, and the three bank owners.{{cite news|last1=Smith|first1=Geoffrey|title=Here's Why Russian Intelligence Bombshell on Donald Trump Might Be Believable|url=http://fortune.com/2017/01/11/donald-trump-intelligence-russian/|accessdate=5 April 2018|work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|date=11 January 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Sommer|first1=Allison Kaplan|title=Controversial Dossier on Trump Alleges That Russia Targets Jewish-American Businessmen|url=https://www.haaretz.com/us-news/leaked-trump-dossier-alleges-that-russia-targets-jewish-americans-1.5484596|accessdate=5 April 2018|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=11 January 2017}} In October 2017 Aven, Fridman, and Khan also filed a libel suit against the private-investigation firm [[Fusion GPS]] and its founder [[Glenn R. Simpson|Glenn Simpson]], who had commissioned former [[MI6]] agent [[Christopher Steele]] to compile the dossier, for circulating the dossier among journalists and allowing it to be published. In May 2018, the Kremlin released a statement noting that Aven, Fridman and Khan were not representing interests of Putin or the Russian government. The statement followed a meeting between the Kremlin, Aven and Fridman.{{Cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/kremlin-says-russian-bankers-weren-t-envoys-to-atlantic-council/4408716.html|title=Kremlin: Russian Bankers Weren't 'Envoys' to Atlantic Council|last=Saakov|first=Rafael|work=VOA|access-date=2018-11-28|language=en}} In April 2018 Aven, Fridman, and Khan filed a libel suit against Steele in the [[Superior Court of the District of Columbia]],{{cite news|last1=Polantz|first1=Katelyn|title=3 Russian oligarchs sue Christopher Steele|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/04/20/politics/oligarchs-lawsuit-christopher-steele/index.html|accessdate=22 April 2018|work=[[CNN]]|date=20 April 2018}}{{cite web|title=Mikhail Fridman, Petr Aven, and German Khan v. Orbis Business Intelligence Limited and Christopher Steele|url=http://cdn.cnn.com/cnn/2018/images/04/20/complaint.from.fridman.against.steele.orbis.in.dc.superior.court.pdf|format=PDF|date=April 16, 2018|access-date=August 20, 2018|via=[[CNN]]}} but the suit was [[dismissed with prejudice]] the following August.{{cite web|title=Russia's Alfa Bank fails in lawsuit over Steele's Trump dossier|url=https://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow/watch/russia-s-alfa-bank-fails-in-lawsuit-over-steele-s-trump-dossier-1303085635995|website=[[MSNBC]]|series=[[The Rachel Maddow Show]]|type=video|date=August 20, 2018|access-date=August 20, 2018}} ==Public activities== Petr Aven holds a number of public facing positions: * A member of the Endowment Foundation Board of Trustees of the [[New Economic School]].[http://www.nes.ru/en/about/management Endowment Foundation Board of Trustees.] New Economic School. Retrieved 14 November 2011. * A trustee of the [[Centre for Economic Policy Research]] (CERP) in [[Great Britain]].[http://www.cepr.org/staff/execcomm.htm CERP Trustees.] CERP. Retrieved 14 November 2011. * A member of the Board of Trustees of the [[Pushkin Museum]] of Fine Arts. * A trustee of the Board of National Association for National Financial Reporting Standards. * A member of the Council of Trustees of the Russian Olympians Foundation.[http://www.olympians.ru/en/site.xp/052056051055.html Council of Trustees.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081013115033/http://www.olympians.ru/en/site.xp/052056051055.html |date=2008-10-13 }} Russian Olympians Foundation. Retrieved 14 November 2011. * A professor at State University [[Higher School of Economics]].[http://www.hse.ru/org/persons/203941 Petr Aven profile.] HSE. Retrieved 14 November 2011. * A member of President’s Council on International Activities of [[Yale University]] (USA).{{cite web|title=President's Council on International Activities|url=http://president.yale.edu/advisory-groups/presidents-council-international-activities|website=Yale University}} * A member of the Presidium of Russian International Affairs Council (RIAC).{{cite web|title=RIAC Presidium|url=http://russiancouncil.ru/en/about-us/presidium/}} Since April 2006, Petr Aven has been a member of the Board of Directors of the [[Russian Union of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs]]. In 2007, Mr. Aven became Chairman of the Russia-Latvian Business Council. Mr. Aven has acted as a guest professor and lecturer at some universities, including Yale University, Bar-Elan University (Israel), and the University of Glasgow and has published two books on econometrics and on economic reform and numerous articles in Russian and international journals, including in Communist Economies and Economic Transformation in Economic Policy. Yale University Press and the Kiel Institute of World Economics, and other scientific and academic institutes have published Mr. Aven's monographs.[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=12663877&privcapId=25037608&previousCapId=13376238&previousTitle=Altimo Petr Aven profile] Businessweek.com. Retrieved 14 November 2011 Aven is a visitor to Western capitals where he gives lectures on economic developments in Russia. He has received a number of international awards, including the best manager in the financial services sector in Russia in 2004 by [[Institutional Investor (magazine)|Institutional Investor]].[http://www.skolkovo.ru/public/en/experts/item/475-experts-aven/ Petr Aven profile.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120402030308/https://www.skolkovo.ru/public/en/experts/item/475-experts-aven/ |date=2012-04-02 }} Skolkovo Experts and Lecturers. Retrieved 14 November 2011. Petr Aven is a supporter of the arts and theatre in Russia. Aven along with [[Stan Polovets]] and three fellow Russian Jewish billionaires, [[Mikhail Fridman]], [[Alexander Knaster]], and [[German Khan]], founded the Genesis Philanthropy Group whose purpose is to develop and enhance Jewish identity among Russian-speaking Jews worldwide.[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/27/world/europe/russians-establish-1-million-jewish-prize-with-israel.html?_r=0 New York Times: "Russians Join Israel to Start Jewish Prize of $1 Million" by David M. Herszenhorn] June 26, 2012[http://www.yadvashem.org/yv/en/about/events/2009/project_genesis.asp Yad Vashem: "Ceremony Marking the Cooperation between Yad Vashem and the Genesis Philanthrophy Group"] June 12, 2009 Aven is also a recognised art collector. His first art purchase was a still life by [[Pavel Kuznetsov]] in 1993, and afterwards he began collecting mostly pre-Soviet Russian art, as well as art by artists of other nationalities.https://www.ft.com/content/f328a740-6233-11e7-8814-0ac7eb84e5f1?mhq5j=e5 Works from his collection have been lent to the [[Jewish Museum]] in Moscow, the Tate in London, the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York and recently the [[Royal Academy]]. In May 2015, pieces from Aven’s private collection were put on display at New York’s Neue Galerie in an exhibition examining early twentieth century Russian art and its relationship with German art of the time.{{cite web|title=From The Director|url=http://www.neuegalerie.org/museum/from-the-director|website=Neue Galerie}} On 3 November 2015, Petr Aven received the [[Woodrow Wilson Awards|Woodrow Wilson Award]] for Corporate Citizenship in recognition of his contribution to corporate and public service to U.S.-Russia relations, at the 2015 Kathryn and Shelby Cullom Davis Awards Dinner. The award was given to Mr Aven in recognition of his many achievements in building understanding between Russians and Americans during his career.{{cite web|title=Petr Aven receives Woodrow Wilson Award in Washington|url=http://www.letterone.com/media/news/2015/petr-aven-receives-woodrow-wilson-award-in-washington-dc}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Aven, Petr}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Politicians from Cape Town]] [[Category:Alfa Group]] [[Category:Russian businesspeople]] [[Category:Russian bankers]] [[Category:Russian billionaires]] [[Category:Moscow State University alumni]] [[Category:National Research University – Higher School of Economics faculty]] [[Category:Democratic Choice of Russia politicians]] [[Category:Russian Jews]] [[Category:Russian people of Jewish descent]] [[Category:Russian people of Latvian descent]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Honour (Russia)]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Friendship]]

'''Philippe Gautier''' is the main author of a "book<ref name="Gautier,Gonzales">{{fr}} "L'Internet des Objets... Internet, mais en mieux", foreword by Gerald Santucci, afterwords by [[Daniel Kaplan (FING)]] et [[Michel Volle]], from main author Philippe Gautier and co-author Laurent Gonzalez, [[AFNOR]] editions, 2011 ({{ISBN|978-2-12-465316-4}})</ref> [about] the history of the understanding of the technological, economic, legal and societal stakes or issues of the "[[Internet of Things]]". This book is actually an essay on the [[Future Internet]] and points out why the contributions of both sciences of [[complexity]] and [[cybernetics]] are necessary in the conception and realization of [[information systems]] to meet the new challenges of sensory technologies - such as [[Near field communication|NFC]], [[RFID]], [[Barcodes]], [[GPS]], etc. - and fully open [[value chains|value chain]]. This essay discusses also the particular impacts on economics, sociology and governance, with a philosophical conclusion.
He is also the founder of [http://www.business2any.com Business2Any], a company specialized in the conception & edition of [[cybernetic]] software, related to [[Distributed Artificial Intelligence]] (DAI), [[machine learning]] & [[cognitive computing]] for the [[Internet of Things]].
He has a long former experience as a [[Chief Information Officer]] which, among other things, allowed him to be the first to implement all [[EPCglobal]] standardized technologies in Europe including RFID/UHF/GEN2, [[EPCIS]] and an independent ONS root ([[Object Naming Service]]<ref>Independent from the one operated by [[VeriSign]] on behalf of [[EPCglobal]]</ref>) in an innovative pilot and at an operational level. The purpose was to manage, in a semi-open loop, the traceability of pallets amongst various logistics players in the supply chain.
He received for his works: * the “[[GS1]] France 2005” price of innovation * the SME Award 2006 (''Le Monde Informatique'') * two trophies for "CIO 2007" (''01 Informatique''): "Winner SMEs" and "Jury Special Prize”.
Last, he is a founding member of the SEI ([http://www.ies-france.eu/ Société européenne de l'Internet/IES France]), regularly write articles, give conferences and act as a consultant for many companies.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * Blog: http://www.i-o-t.org * Press review: http://www.i-o-t.org/pages/Community-manager * Regular chronicles : http://www.atelier.net/authors/philippe-gautier * Quotations on the ies-France website: http://www.ies-france.eu/projet/search/gautier/ * Interview: 3 questions to Philippe Gautier : http://www.i-o-t.org/post/3questionstoPhilippeGAUTIERbyDavidFayon * Twitter : @neuzemayo
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gautier, Philippe}} [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:French computer scientists]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:French businesspeople]] [[Category:Chief information officers]]

'''Pier Francesco Guarguaglini''' (born 1937 in [[Tuscany]], Italy) is an Italian engineer, university educator and businessman. He is best known for his nine-year term (2002–2011) as chairman of [[Finmeccanica]] (since 2017 Leonardo), a partly state-owned Italian aerospace and defence conglomerate.
==Biography== Guarguaglini was born in Tuscany in 1937. He studied electrical engineering at the [[University of Pisa]] and Collegio Pacinotti of [[Scuola Normale Superiore di Pisa]] (present day [[Sant'Anna School of Advanced Studies]]), then received his [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]] from the [[University of Pennsylvania]].
Gargauglini began his career as an assistant lecturer in nuclear electronics at the University of Pisa. He later became an assistant lecturer in radar systems at the [[Sapienza University of Rome|University of Rome]], remaining there for 15 years. He also worked for nearly 20 years at Italian electronics firm [[Alenia Aeronautica|Selenia]] in various managerial positions.<ref>[https://books.google.com] ''Pier Francesco Guarguaglini Bio'', google books (website)</ref>
His various industry positions include general manager, and later chief executive officer, of Officine Galileo (1984–94); a managing director of Oto Melara and Breda Meccanica Bresciana (1994–96); head of Finmeccanica Defence Consortium (1996–99); chairman of the board of directors of Alenia Marconi Systems (1998–2000); chief executive officer of Fincantiere SPA and Cantieri Navali Itaniani (Italy's largest shipbuilding consortium)(1999–2002).
In 2002 Guarguaglini returned to Finmeccanica, being named to the posts of chief executive officer and president on 24 April.
While at Finmeccanica, he also remained busy elsewhere. He was an independent lecturer at the University of Rome, and was named an independent director of [[Eutelsat]] Communications on 26 July 2007. He sat on the counsels of [[Confindustria]], and AECMA (European Association of Aerospace Industries, later changed to AeroSpace and Defence Industries Association of Europe).<ref>[http://executivepeoples.com/pier-francesco-guarguaglini/] ''Pier Francesco Guarguaglini'', Executive People Biography (website)</ref> He was a member of IEEE (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers), and served as a member of the IEEE board representing the United States and Italy.<ref>google books</ref>
Gargauglini received an Honorary Doctorate from [[Heriot-Watt University]] in 2010 <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www1.hw.ac.uk/ppr/docs/network-winter-2010.pdf|title=Honorary Graduates 2010|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160412085029/http://www1.hw.ac.uk/ppr/docs/network-winter-2010.pdf|archivedate=2016-04-12|df=}}</ref>
==Departure from Finmeccanica== Guarguaglini had been nominated to head the Finmeccanica group by the Italian Finance Ministry, which holds some 30 percent of the company's stock. He was considered extremely successful in restoring the company's position in the worldwide industry - under his direction, Finmeccanica gained full control of European helicopter company [[AgustaWestland]] in 2004, and used that control to win the competition to provide [[Marine One|helicopter transportation for the President of the United States]] in 2005. Partly in recognition of this success, US industry magazine [[Aviation Week & Space Technology]] named him its 2005 Person Of The Year.<ref>Person of the Year 2005-2012, ''Aviation Week & Space Technology'', 14 January 2013 issue, p. 47</ref> He gained a greater foothold in the US aviation electronics market by purchasing the US electronics fabricator DRS Technologies Inc. in 2008.
By 2009, Italian investigators were looking into bribery charges that had been leveled at several Italian companies. They tried to determine whether executives at one of Finmeccanica's divisions, Selex Sistemi Integrati, had inflated the value of contracts with an air-traffic manager, then used the resulting funds to bribe various politicians. That division was managed by Guarguaglini's wife, Marina Grossi. By early 2011 the government (as represented by Prime Minister [[Mario Monti]]) was convinced that a top-to-bottom shakeout of Finmeccanica management was necessary, and in April 2011 they brought in Giuseppi Orsi (born 1945) to replace Guarguaglini as chief executive officer. Guarguaglini retained responsibility for company strategy, acquisitions, asset sales, and government relations.
The dual-manager situation proved difficult, however, and on 1 December 2011,<ref>{{cite news|title=Scandal at Finmeccanica Revives Questions in Italy|first=Elisabetta|last=Provoledo|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/01/business/global/scandal-at-finmeccanica-revives-questions-in-italy.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=30 November 2011}}</ref> Guarguaglini held a showdown with the board of directors in an attempt to more clearly define the division of responsibilities between the two managers. Unable to achieve his desired goad, he submitted his resignation effective immediately. It was accepted, and he received a 4.5 million-euro payout on his remaining contract, with another 1.5 million-euro payment at the end of a one-year non-compete agreement.<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-12-01/finmeccanica-s-guarguaglini-faces-showdown-with-board-amid-probe.html] Finmeccanica Chairman Guarguaglini Resigns Amid Probe; Orsi Assumes Role, ''Bloomberg News'', 1 December 2011</ref> In June 2014, Guarguaglini was placed under house arrest in connection with the Sistri bribery probe.<ref>https://www.thelocal.it/20140630/ex-finmeccanica-chief-arrested-in-bribery-probe</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Leonardo-Finmeccanica}}

use ''Name (1950–present)'' --> | children = | parents = | relatives = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | module = | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | footnotes = | box_width = }}
'''Qais Al Khonji''' ([[Arabic]]: قيس الخنجي) is an [[Omani people|Omani]] [[Business people|businessman]] and [[entrepreneur]]. He is the founder of ''Qais United Enterprises Trading'' and ''Genesis International''.<ref>{{cite web | last= | first= | title=Qais Al-Khonji, Co-Owner, Genesis International | publisher=The Prospectus Group| date=12 November 2012| url= http://www.theprospectgroup.com/executivefocus/profile/qais-al-khonji-co-owner-genesis-international/81057/| accessdate = 13 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =INC Staff Writer | first =. | coauthors = | title =Business In Oman Is More Than Just Profit For Qais Al-Khonji |newspaper =Industry News Corp | location= | pages = | language = | publisher = | date=18 November 2012 | url=http://www.industrynewscorp.com/business-in-oman-is-more-than-just-profit-for-qais-al-khonji/| accessdate =13 December 2012 }}</ref> He serves as a board member for many [[Economy of Oman|Omani companies]] and is known for assisting [[Omani people|Omani citizens]] with overcoming the hurdles of starting [[small business]]es in the country.<ref>{{cite news| title =Obstacles: Perception vs Reality| newspaper =Oman Economic Review| location =| pages =| language =| publisher =| date =13 December 2011| url =http://www.oeronline.com/php/2012/july/cover.php| accessdate =13 December 2012| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20121210042633/http://www.oeronline.com/php/2012/july/cover.php| archivedate =10 December 2012| df =}}</ref>
He is also the co-owner and CEO of Genesis International, a medical education company based in Oman.<ref>{{cite news | last =Lopes | first =Andrea | coauthors = | title =Practical Selling | newspaper =Business Today | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =April 2013 | url =http://www.businesstoday.co.om/disCon.aspx?Cval=1572 | accessdate =21 June 2013 }}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last =Bhattacharjee | first =Madhuparna | coauthors = | title =New Oman Firm To Promote Medical Tourism In India | newspaper =Muscat Daily | location = | pages = | language = | publisher = | date =19 January 2013 | url = http://www.muscatdaily.com/Archive/Oman/New-Omani-firm-to-promote-medical-tourism-in-India-1zdp | accessdate =21 June 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news| last =| first =| coauthors =| title =Education In Indian Made Simpler| newspaper =Oman Observer| location =| pages =| language =| publisher =| date =30 January 2013| url =http://main.omanobserver.om/node/143785| archive-url =https://archive.is/20130628170104/http://main.omanobserver.om/node/143785| dead-url =yes| archive-date =28 June 2013| accessdate =21 June 2013}}</ref>
==Early and Personal Life== He was born in [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]], [[Oman]]. Al Khonji is married with two kids: Ziena and Mahmoud.{{Citation needed|date=November 2015}}
==Study== Qais Al-Khonji graduated from [[Atlantic College]] in [[Wales]] in 1998, obtaining his [[International Baccalaureate]] Diploma. Following his graduation, he moved to [[Leicester]], [[England]] that same year and finished his bachelor's degree in business information systems in [[De Montfort University]].<ref>[http://qaisalkhonji.com "Qais al-Khonji, Oman Businessman"]</ref>
==Work Experience== In 2010, Qais decided to begin his own business, Qais United, which was a simple trading company that bought goods from China and sold them to individuals.<ref>[http://qaisalkhonji.com "Qais al-Khonji, Oman Businessman"]</ref>
In the year 2012, Qais established his second company (Genesis International), which is currently providing IT solutions, in addition to trying to implement the so-called (Smart City), which should facilitate electronic payment of bills for water and electricity within a certain population range. The company is now seeking to try to apply this system in the Omani capital [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]] and some parts of [[India]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Genesis International Co-Owner Qais Al-Khonji on entrepreneurship in Oman|url=http://www.theprospectgroup.com/qais-al-khonji-co-owner-genesis-international-81057/|website=The Prospect Group}}</ref>
In 2013, Qais established a successful enhanced oil recovery business called Genesis Projects and Investments LLC - EOR Lab Services and he is currently running it.<ref>{{cite web|title=Business Start-Up Tips From Leading Omani Entrepreneur [Interview]|url=http://guardianlv.com/2014/11/business-start-up-tips-from-leading-omani-entrepreneur-interview/|website=Guardian Liberty Voice}}</ref>
Also, Al-Khonji is a board member of [[Oman Fisheries]] since 2006, a board member of [[Oman National Engineering & Investment CO.]] since 2009, a board member of [[Sharakah]] which specifically encourages and supports the development of entrepreneurs and SMEs in the [[Oman]] since 2011.<ref>[http://timesofoman.com/article/66493/Business/Economy/Oman-Vision-2020-is-a-strategy-aimed-at-boosting-industrialisation-and-encouraging-more-private-investment-in-the-economy-and-jobs-market "Qais Al Khonji: The voice of entrepreneurship in Oman"], ''Times of Oman'', 29 August 2015. Accessed 4 September 2015.</ref> Qais is also a board member of Muscat National Holding since 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Muscat National Holding - Board of Directors|url=http://www.muscatnationalholding.com/directors.html|website=Muscat National Holding}}</ref>
He has also been recognized by his government as a representative of the country and was appointed as a member of the [[Entrepreneurs' Organization]] to meet with former Indian [[A. P. J. Abdul Kalam|President Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam]] to discuss [[India–Oman relations|Indian-Omani business relations]].<ref>{{cite web | last=EO Staff Global | first= | title=Former India President Meets With EO Oman | publisher=Entrepreneurs’ Organization| date=| url= http://www.eonetwork.org/press/mitn/pages/formerindiapresidentmeetswitheooman.aspx| accessdate = 13 December 2012}}</ref>
In 2015, he was chosen as Business Worldwide Magazine's 'Social Entrepreneur of the Year' for Oman.<ref>[http://www.tradearabia.com/news/IND_289505.html "Al-Khonji wins 'Social Entrepreneur of the Year Oman’ award"], ''Trade Arabia'', 3 September 2015. Accessed 4 September 2015.</ref>
Qais, was listed among the top 10 [[Persian Gulf|Gulf]] Business Entrepreneurs, by [[Times of Oman]] in 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://timesofoman.com/article/114366/Business/Omani-businessman-listed-among-Gulfs-top-10-talented-entrepreneurs|title=Omani businessman listed among Gulf’s top 10 talented entrepreneurs|work=Times of Oman|access-date=2017-09-05|language=en-GB}}</ref>
==Other Resources==
# [http://www.genesisoman.com/index.html Genesis projects & Investments LLC] # [https://twitter.com/qaisalkhonji Qais Al-Khonji Twitter Account]
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Ramón Tamayo''' (1921–2008) was a [[Spain|Spanish]] producer, businessman and [[impresario]].<ref name=Esteban>{{cite news|last=Esteban|first=Rafael|title=Ramón Tamayo, empresario y productor teatral (English: Ramón Tamayo, Businessman and theatre producer) (in Spanish)|url= http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2008/06/24/obituarios/1214301147.html|accessdate=29 June 2012|newspaper=El Mundo|date=24 June 2008}}</ref> He was born in [[Granada (province)|Granada]] in 1921 and died in [[Madrid]] on June 23, 2008.<ref name="Diario Ideal">{{cite news|last=Diario Ideal|title=Muere a los 87 años Ramón Tamayo, ex director del Centro Dramático Nacional (English: Ramón Tamayo, former director of the National Dramatic Center dies at 87 years of age) (in Spanish)|url= http://www.ideal.es/granada/20080624/cultura/muere-anos-ramon-tamayo-20080624.html|accessdate=29 June 2012|newspaper=Agencias Diario Ideal|date=24 June 2008}}</ref>
==Career== Ramón Tamayo worked as a producer for nearly three decades in the Lope de Vega company, founded by his brother Joseph Tamayo in 1946,<ref name=Torres>{{cite news|last=Torres|first=Rosana|title=Ramón Tamayo, productor teatral (English: Ramón Tamayo, Theatre producer) (in Spanish)|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/Necrologicas/Ramon/Tamayo/productor/teatral/elpepinec/20080624elpepinec_4/Tes|accessdate=29 June 2012|newspaper=El País|date=24 June 2008}}</ref> with which he toured the Spanish territory making known the new generation of foreign authors during the Franco regime.
He directed the National Drama Centre between 1979 and 1981 along with actors [[Nuria Espert]] and [[José Luis Gómez (actor)|José Luis Gómez]]. While the latter two were responsible for art direction, Tamayo took care of the inner workings, management and production.<ref name=Esteban>{{cite news|last=Esteban|first=Rafael|title=Ramón Tamayo, empresario y productor teatral (English: Ramón Tamayo, Businessman and theatre producer) (in Spanish)|url= http://www.elmundo.es/elmundo/2008/06/24/obituarios/1214301147.html|accessdate=29 June 2012|newspaper=El Mundo|date=24 June 2008}}</ref> During his tenure, the center hosted around twenty shows such as ''Los baños de Argel'' (The Algiers baths), directed by Francisco Nieva; ''La velada en Benicarl,'' (Vigil in Benicarl) directed by ( Manuel Azaña).
With other companies he produced ''Sueño de una noche de verano'' (Dream of a summer's night), from Lindsay Kemp as well as debutting other plays in a national theater - the Theatre Lliure and the Els Joglars.<ref name=Torres>{{cite news|last=Torres|first=Rosana|title=Ramón Tamayo, productor teatral (English: Ramón Tamayo, Theatre producer) (in Spanish)|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/Necrologicas/Ramon/Tamayo/productor/teatral/elpepinec/20080624elpepinec_4/Tes|accessdate=29 June 2012|newspaper=El País|date=24 June 2008}}</ref>
After a stint in the public theater, Tamayo returned to the private, back to the Lope de Vega company and the Fine Arts Theatre, where he directed with his brother until 2003, when his brother died. Ramón Tamayo died five years later in Madrid at the age of 87 years.<ref name="Diario Ideal">{{cite news|last=Diario Ideal|title=Muere a los 87 años Ramón Tamayo, ex director del Centro Dramático Nacional (English: Ramón Tamayo, former director of the National Dramatic Center dies at 87 years of age) (in Spanish)|url= http://www.ideal.es/granada/20080624/cultura/muere-anos-ramon-tamayo-20080624.html|accessdate=29 June 2012|newspaper=Agencias Diario Ideal|date=24 June 2008}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
